text:
In a word, WONDERLICIOUS!  I knocked this recipe out of the park on my first try.  Here's what I did (and what you should do too): in melted butter, sauté 2 minced garlic cloves, 1 cup chopped onion, 1 cup chopped celery, and 1 cup sliced carrots.  Meanwhile, chop 1/2 pound uncooked boneless, skinless chicken breast into bite-size pieces. Add chicken, the broth, basil, oregano, salt, garlic pepper, a dash or two of poultry seasoning, and a pinch or two of dried thyme to the pot of veggies. Bring to a boil, reduce heat, cover and simmer 20 minutes.  Meanwhile, cook 3 cups egg noodles according to package directions in a separate pot.  Add drained noodles to chicken and veggies, simmer an additional 10 minutes. Only if you want some creaminess, go ahead and add a half can of condensed cream of whatever soup (whatever flavor you choose).  Voilà! A SIX-star chicken noodle soup!

text:
Vincenza...I could kiss you for this recipe.  My 15 month old and I had a bad flu and she refused to eat any soup from the can.  I was ill and at my wits end and found this recipe.  I had all ingredients in the house (except for celery) and whipped this together.  I didn't have the vegetable broth and had to improvise with some chicken broth granules to make all the necessary broth.  I cubed raw chicken and boiled it in the soup to save time.  I also added garlic.  I made egg noodles on the side and added it as we ate it so the soup wouldn't get starchy.  This soup was not only easy but AMAZING!  Probably the best chicken soup I've eaten.  UPDATE:  I'm still eating this on a regular weekly basis.  I make a batch almost weekly and it freezes excellent (if you don't add pasta to it until you're ready to serve).  I now ALWAYS use vegetable broth as I really feel it adds to the flavor.  I sautee the celery, onions and carrots along with garlic to soften them up.  I also buy a rotisserie chicken and use the whole thing to make a huge batch of this soup.  I triple all veggies and my 20 month old daughter eats the veggies out of the soup by the handful!  This freezes REALLY well if you don't add pasta until you're ready to serve.  This is a definite keeper and is still the best homemade chicken soup I've had.

text:
GREAT recipe! A few changes I made are...I sauteed the carrots along with the onion (they end up more tender), I didn't use any veg broth but all homemade chicken broth (it's richer), I added minced garlic along with the othe veggies that cook in the butter, and I doubled the noodles (this made it more a chicken & noodles dish but it was delish!).  This is a great way to usue a rotisserie (sp?) chicken on the second day.  I really really recommend this recipe! I also freezes well!

I used all chicken broth (part homemade & part store bought broth in the box)  Used fresh basil and fresh oregano from my garden and threw in some dried herbes de provence(an incredibly versatile herb mixture)Sauteed the sliced carrots with the onion and celery.  Made the recipe for 8 and that made generous servings for 6 people. Everyone had 2 bowls.  Delicious. Served with big green salad, rolls, fresh fruit and brownies for dessert.

text:
I followed the recipe only adding 6 cloves of minced garlic. I used homemade chicken broth/vegetable broth and I used the "No Yolks" egg noodles. After tasting it, I did increase the basil and oregano. This was quick to make and quite comforting for someone who's been sick for what seems like ages. Next time, I'll increase both the onion and celery as I like a chunkier soup.

text:
This was the first homemade chicken noodle soup I ever made. It is VERY GOOD! I was expecting something different than the way it turned out, but it is delicious all the same. I did nearly doubly the noodles and I doubled the veggies. The only problem I had was that the noodles lost their spiral shape when the soup was done--they cooked too long. I may cook them separately next time. 

I have to say...while I am sure there are better recipes out there somewhere, this one is quick, cheap, and easy! And as another reviewer said, it makes me not want to buy another canned chicken noodles soup again. And I don't think that I will unless I have to! I really like this! Good and flavorful!

text:
Excellent chicken noodle soup recipe.  Very easy and has a homemade taste.  I did not cook the chicken first.  I simmered it in the broth with the vegetables for more flavor.  Used frozen egg noodles and added garlic.  Also added two cans of condensed cream of chicken soup for a creamier soup.  I would recommend tasting it before adding salt, it may not be necessary to add salt if not using low sodium chicken broth.

text:
Love the recipe with my tweaks! I've made this quite a few times now - usually in the slow cooker. I skip sauteing the veggies ahead of time and just dump everything in the slow cooker. I use 2 boxes of the 32 ounce chicken  broth and omit the vegetable broth. I add the spices already included in the recipe and include a dash of cayenne and a liberal sprinkling of parmesan cheese. I then throw in 2 frozen chicken breasts - some may want to add 3, but 2 is fine for my family of four. I let cook on high for about 4 hours. After the 4 hours most of the chicken has already fallen apart into pieces, what ever hasn't can easily be torn apart/separated in the slow cooker before serving.

text:
This is so easy, and I've made some changes to make it even easier.  Saute the carrots along with the onions and celery.  After adding and heating the broths, add raw cubed chicken breast pieces and simmer for 20-30 minutes.  Ten minutes before you are ready to serve, add egg noodles.  Simmer for 5 minutes and then turn off the heat.  Let the soup sit for five minutes more.  Only one pot to wash!

text:
This recipe is good, except that the already cooked chicken breast will be dry and mealy by the time you cook it another 20 minutes.  Consider using whole boneless skinless thighs, cook in the broth for 20 minutes, remove, chop, return, and cook perhaps 5 minutes longer.

text:
This has become one of my favorite chicken soup recipes--easy, hearty, and flavorful. I increased the veggies to 1 cup onion, 1 cup celery, and 2 cups carrots. Also, I like the richness that broth takes on when I use uncooked chicken, so I added four boneless, skinless thighs and simmered them with the vegetables for 20 minutes, removed them to cool, shredded the meat, and returned it to the pot. Instead of noodles I used elbow macaroni, since that's all I had on hand, but I didn't want it to soak up the broth so I boiled it separately and added it to the soup along with the shredded chicken. Yummy, yummy with a big salad and sliced French bread. Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
I've been making this for years. I also put ground thyme and ground rosemary to sweeten it. I don't precook the onion and celery. I cook them with the chicken and carrots. The chicken is already chppped and don't take that long to cook. They don't get soft and mushy. They have a lil firmness.  To thicken the broth a lil I use 1/4 cup of corn starch and 1/4 cup of water. Stir that before adding to broth then when broth is boiling add it. I throw in the noodles 10 minutes before it's done.

Display Name:
UDscoobychick

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/116753.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent, especially with the tricks I used that made this a 1-pot meal!  I used 1 onion, 3-4 celery ribs, and 4 medium carrots for the veggies, diced them sauteed them all together until the onions were translucent, then added 2 Tbl minced garlic and sauteed a minute or two more.  Meanwhile, I cut raw chicken into bite-sized pieces, then threw it in the pot with the veggies.  Added 5 cans low sodium chicken broth, basil, oregano, pepper, and poultry seasoning, and simmered for about 15 minutes.  Then added in about 2 c egg noodles and simmered for another 8 minutes.  Mixed 2 Tbl. cornstarch with 1/4 c. water, and poured that in, and simmered another 1-2 min, until slightly thickened.  Removed from heat and swirled in 1/2 c. fat free half-and-half.  Delicious, thick, creamy, satisfying, and only one pot to clean!

This was my first try at chicken noodle soup and it was so good.  Figured with it being 16 degrees outside and having a killer sore throat, this was the perfect thing to make.  I didn't measure exactly.  I used double the amount of veggies.  Diced up uncooked chicken and cooked along with all veggies including carrots with some garlic and s&p.  Used a 48 oz box of chicken broth and a 32 oz box of veggie broth and added 1/2 tsp dried thyme.  I also cooked my noodles separately.  So easy, so good, and really hit the spot.  Thanks so much!

text:
Made as written I give this a 4 star rating however when adjusted for our tastes this becomes a 5 star rating in our house. I used homemade chicken stock and I added fresh minced garlic when cooking the onions in a bit of olive oil and once cooked down I added my carrots and celery to the onion/garlic and cooked for about 5 minuets. I played around with the seasoning a bit also and added some frozen corn to the soup. I made homemade egg noodles using the "Grandma's Noodles" recipe from this site, added during the last few minuets of cooking. Fantastic! make extra to freeze for an easy sick day meal.

text:
Made for my husband last night - I, myself, don't care for chicken noodle soup.  He said it was very good.  We're both doing weight watchers - that being said, always struggle with finding out the portion size.  For those who like to know portion size (to get 6 portions out of a batch), it's 1 1/2 cups each.  For 2012  points based on nutritional info - it came out to 4 points per serving & 7 pts for two servings.

This soup is excellent. I didn't have veggie juice so I just substituted more chicken broth. I eliminated the salt because I made the broth with boullion crystals (already more salt than I wanted:). I increased the basil and oregano to 1 tsp. each and added 1 tsp. garlic flakes. Thanks!

text:
This is an awesome recipe! I make it on a regular basis for our family of 6, and love bringing it to families in need of a meal (sick, new baby etc) Everyone is always asking me for the recipe. After a few tries, I did end up increasing all of the veggies to 1 cup each, substituting more chicken broth for the vegetable broth, adding 2 garlic cloves, and a few pinches of thyme and poultry seasoning. I also always double the entire recipe and use a whole rotisserie chicken shredded. To me, the key ingredient is the type of egg noodles that you use. I tried several and then came across Pennsylvania Dutch Kluski Egg Noodles at Walmart. Incredible! My dad tasted the soup and asked me if I made the noodles from scratch because they tasted just like his mom's. Now, they are the only noodles I use for this soup and everyone is happy about that!

text:
I had the breast with skin from a rotisserie chicken.  I sauteed celery onion and carrots in butter with a little olive oil.  Olive oil will help to stop the butter from burning. Added 3 pressed garlic cloves the last minute. added broth. Removed bones and skin from the chicken.  added them with the broth. There's a lot of good flavor in them. Removed them before adding diced up  chicken & added that when I added noodles. Didn't have oregano or basil so I used Italian seasoning and 2 bay leaves.  If you're worried about not getting all the bones out of the soup tie them up in a piece of cheese cloth. It was just great to go to the pantry & the fridge & find everything I needed w/o going shopping!!!!I did simmer this for a little over an hour before adding cut up chicken. House smells like you've been slaving away all day.  09/04/09 I made this soup again  today the same way and it was not has good  It was good but not great. I do believe it was because I made my own broth & I did not use a rotisserie ckn.  A rotisserie ckn has all the extra flavors in it already. Will definitely make it again but with a rotisserie ckn.

FABULOUS!!! I make this recipe all the time and it is a winner. The only thing I do different is to make my own noodles, I love homemade noodles and they are yummy in this soup, and add garlic. text:
Easy and quick! To give you an idea of just how easy, my husband and I tag teamed this and made it when we both had the flu. He did some chopping, I did the sauteeing. Following others' recommendations, I first sauteed raw chicken cut into bite size pieces, in olive oil. When they were cooked on most sides, I added all the veggies (plus a couple cloves of chopped garlic) and sauteed it for about 10 minutes. Added 2 cartons of chicken stock plus 2 cups water. Simmered 20 minutes, added egg noodles (about 4 cups), simmered another 10, ate! It was a tad on the bland side, but that was good since we were sick and needed something that was easy to get down. That's why 4 instead of 5 stars. 5 for ease and quickness for sure!

Fabulous recipe!  It wasn't tons of work, but full of flavor!  I made a few minor changes: Doubled the veggies and noodles (since we are HUGE funs of Campbell's Chunky Chicken Noodle Soup), only had 4 cans of chicken broth on hand and ended up using half a can of beef broth....it was great!! text:
Was looking around AR.com to find a recipe that didn't have stock from scratch-- who has the time?  So, I finally found this one where I used canned chicken & Veggie Broth and it was perfect!

Followed it to a T except:  I also sauteed the carrots with the onion and celery-- it helped soften them.  I also added lots of garlic & sauteed that, too.  I waited til the onions were translucent and then threw in the broth.  Cooked it over 20 mins (I like my veggies soft, like the canned version) and added a 1 cup of water to compensate for evaporation.  I was worried that it would water down the broth but it didn't at all.  I ran out of chicken broth (used 4 cans instead of 5 total) so that extra cup of water was needed.  Instead of noodles I cooked matzoh balls in a separate pot since I like those better.  Added the balls (already fully cooked) right before serving.  Perfectly delicious! Too Jays matzoh ball soup can eat it's heart out!

city:

None
country:
None
text:
EXCELLENT!

Here are a couple of my recommendations:

1) Double the Onion and Celery
2) I use 20oz of Chicken Breast
3) Cook the chicken for 20 minutes IN the broth/veggie mix, don't worry about pre-cooking it.  Once it's cooked, take it out and chopped into bite size pieces.
4) Add the cooked chicken and noodles into the pot and cook for 10 minutes or until noodles are done.

Saves time and tastes great!

Low Sodium Chicken Broth worked great for me...I'd rather slowly add salt and have control over how much goes in.

Enjoy!  I know I did...

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
As a novice cook, I chose this recipe largely because it didn't involve boiling a chicken carcass to make my own broth, the way my mom always did. While it's not QUITE as good as the true all-from-scratch soups, it's definitely the next best thing, and so much easier! It beats canned soup by a long shot. 

Bear in mind that this recipe gets much of its flavor from the chicken broth you choose, so make sure to get one you really like. I went with Swanson broth and it came out with a flavor reminiscent of ramen noodles (which I happen to like), but if you're pickier you might want to look for something high-end or make your own.

text:
I made this following the recipe exactly the first time. The second time I left out the vegetable broth, added 6 Cups Chicken Stock, 2 Cups water and 2 Cans of Cream of Chicken soup. Also, I added about 2 cloves of minced garlic to the onion at the beginning and I cooked the chicken in the broth for about twenty minutes before removing it to cut it up and then I added it back in at the end and I added peas at the same time as the noodles. For the seasonings the only additions I made were adding 1 tsp of Parsely and 1 tsp of Poultry seasoning. Both times it was very good, just a bit more personalized the second time around.

My family loves chicken soup,but it is usually made in a large pot from scratch and takes about 3 hours.It is delecious.However my wife was out and my kids had colds and I didnt have time to cook soup for 3 hours.I tried this recipie and my kids absolutely loved loved loved it.It was quick easy and tasted great.Soup from scratch is a little richer tasting but this was a huge hit.My mom could not believe it took less than 40 minutes to cook.She has made chicken soup from scratch for years and she asked for the recipie so she can make a quick chicken soup.Only complaint is that if your making it for alot of people buying all that broth can get a little pricy,otherwise it was great.Kids asked me to make it twice already in the last 3 weeks.great and quick chicken noodle soup.5 stars.

None
text:
This recipe was a wonderful find! My son didn't like any of the canned soups I tried, and I hardly ever have time to make it completely from scratch. Both kids and my wife love this recipe! I've found I like it better with all chicken broth. I don't often have leftover chicken, so I just cook up some boneless chicken breasts (or sometimes boneless thighs) in butter and garlic, along with some fresh, chopped baby carrots instead of onions. (My kids don't like onions, though I snuck in some finely chopped ones once and they didn't complain much) The family prefers it with the egg noodles cooked in, as they like it to thicken. I sometimes throw in some frozen peas towards the end, for extra veggies. I really appreciate this recipe, and how it's flexible and tasty and fast!

text:
I've made this several times now, and it's terrific.  The first time I tried it I wasn't in a carrot mood, so I substituted a can of diced tomatoes which tastes great and makes the broth look nice.  It's a flexible recipe, and I'll try it with the carrots sometime.  Also, I double the oregano and basil and add garlic as others suggested.  I omit the saute in butter step and just cook the onions and garlic in the broth.  It still tastes great and is even lower in fat.  A keeper recipe.

text:
I enjoyed this soup.  Definitely not as good as 100% from scratch soup but an acceptable substitute when you don't have time.  I followed the directions to the letter except for I added my chicken breast raw, did not have the problem of the foam on top.  The basil and oregano give it a different flavor, not like traditional chicken soup that I'm used to, I almost left it out but I wanted to give the original recipe a chance, and I'm glad I did as the broth was tasty.  Next time I'm going to add some peas to up the veggies.  Here's a tip: the 900 mL Campbells (or Knorr)chicken broth in a carton is equivalent to 3 cans of soup.  Thanks for the recipe.

text:
I cooked according to the instructions, except that I made the following modifications (most taken from previous comments): (1) I used cooking spray instead of the butter; (2) I used 1 cup of celery instead of 1/2 cup; (3) When I cooked the onions and celery, I also added in the carrots and two cloves of garlice; (4) I kept the noodles separate from the soup mixture until serving; and(5) just prior to serving, I added to the soup mixture: a can of cream of chicken soup and a can of cream of celery soup. It was a great solution to a cold night in Texas. My husband liked it.

text:
This may be the best chicken noodle soup I have ever had!  I used  one can of cream of chicken soup as others have suggested. You will need to stir this a long time to get it blended.  Also, I used an 11 oz. can of  V-8 because I could not find veg. broth.    I added about a cup of water to cut down the saltiness of the V-8.  I would suggest using small egg noodles.  I used the extra wide kind because that was what I had on hand and they are too big for your spoon. This soup looks and tastes restaurant quality.  Thanks Vincenza!

text:
People get mad when other people alter recipes and then rate and review, well I feel differently. I read them because I love all the alterations that people make and generally I tend to take the most frequently used substitutions. I rated this soup only 4 stars because honestly if you made it as is, this soup would be EXTREMELY bland. I love that its quick and easy and a great way to a quick "homemade" chicken noodle soup. I used chicken stock instead of broth and I did use the 1 can of veggie soup. I also added 1 can of cream of chicken and 1 can of cream of mushroom which really brought this soup to life. For the chicken I just brought a whole rottiserie chicken and shredded that in my soup. I cant say I followed the  measurements to a tea, which is why I added so much broth, but overall the concept of this soup is really good.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I always make a new recipe exactly as instructed the first time; then I can tweak it to my tastes. As written, this is pretty good. There are only two things I would change:

1) Cook the carrots with the onion and celery before adding the other ingredients; they weren't totally hard, but they weren't nice and tender, either.

2) The noodles get too mushy if you add them with the broth. Next time, I will let the broth and vegetables cook for a little while and then add the noodles later on.

Otherwise, this was a tasty meal. I served it with a baguette and a fresh salad. Yum!

text:
I make this in Two stages. Sauté celery,carrots and onion with basil, oregano, salt and pepper. Add broths and carrcus of rotisserie chicken  (pull 1/2 breast off and save for sandwiches, use rest for soup). Simmer one hour, strain and start over with fresh veggies. Add noodles you cooked prior. Good stuff Maynard.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe!! I sauteed minced garlic and diced onions together in butter...then added carrots, celery, and red potatoes. Added a little bit of broth (homemade veggie and turkey from left over thanksgiving turkey bones) and let that simmer for awhile to soften up the potatoes...cooked the chicken in separate pan and then added together with the rest of the broth...seasoned with basil and oregano....cooked spaghetti noodles while this was simmering and added to it when they were done! perfect....fyi about broth- save all your onion, celery, carrot scraps and then when you have a decent amount buy some mushrooms and throw all in pot, cover with water, bring to boil, and simmer for 1-2 hours...strain and done- you have broth. I fill 2 cups at a time in freezer bags and save for whenever I am ready...havent bought broth in a year....can do this while whole chicken carcasses as well

this was the absolute best chicken noodle soup! Hubby was sick and what's better than chicken noodle soup. I sauted the carrots,celery,onions,and garlic in butter before i added the broth. our store did not have veggie broth so i used 4 cans of chicken broth (not low sodium) and one of the broth cans filled with water and mixed with a chicken bouilloin cube. i also added just a pinch of poultry seasoning, garlic powder and thyme, and added half a can of cream of chicken. The best!!! you cannot go wrong with this recipe. Im actually looking forward to making this again :)

This soup was exactly what my family needed since 3 out of the 4 of us has a pretty nasty cold. The only thing I did differently was I put in the chicken uncooked, only because I forgot to cook it beforehand. It was a happy mistake because in the end the chicken had a great flavor from cooking in the broths and herbs. I will always use uncooked chicken for now on. I also threw in more noodles then called for. My kids love the noodles and 1 1/2 cups just wouldn't cut it. This was a wonderful recipe and I will start making this more often...even when we're not under the weather.

Instead of canned broth I used strained broth left over from stewing chicken on 2 other recent occasions. This soup was awesome and will be a keeper in my recipe box! After I added the noodles, I also added 1/2 cup frozen corn and 1/2 cup frozen peas, 1 scant teaspoon poultry seasoning, 1 tsp seasoned salt, and 1 tbsp beef base, since I don't use salt when stewing chickens, it needed a little seasoning boost. Thanks for the post! Wonderful!

text:
This is really good soup.  I omitted the vegetable broth and used about 2 cups of extra broad egg noodles and the end result was really yummy, satisfying (not to mention super quick) chicken noodle soup to help comfort my sick hubby (although I did have to add more broth than the recipe called for, in part because of the extra egg noodles I added).  I will most definitely make this soup again, but I will add more vegetables (probably double what the recipe calls for).  I also want to note that I used 3 medium cloves of garlic which I added when sauteeing the onions, celery and carrots.  I also added 1 package of chicken bouillon for added flavour.  Thanks for a great recipe.

I made this tonight for my husband and my 2 year old daughter who can be a bit picky.  We all loved it!  My daughter ate all her carrots (and she doesn't like carrots)!  I am not a fan of chicken noodle soup and I also really enjoyed this.  I followed the advice of other and sauteed the carrots and some garlic with the other veggies.  I used "Finding Nemo" pasta as it is easier for my 2 year old to eat.  I also used rotisserie chicken from Costco.  As a working mom I will definitely pass this recipe on to my friends and co-workers.  This is so quick and easy for those of us who love to cook but just don't have the time.

text:
What an amazing dinner tonight although I really only used this recipe as a guideline.  I started with Homemade Chicken Broth from this site.  That gave me about 9 cups of broth.  I sauteed my carrots (20 chopped baby carrots) along with my celery (2 stalks chopped) and onion (1/2 medium).  I followed th rest of the recipe but didn't add the pasta (between 1/2 - 3/4 lb rotini) until the simmer.  I needed to add some water since I was using a heavier pasta.  I then added for more flavor about 1 tsp ginger and 1 tsp red pepper flakes.  I added a little parmesan too for family preference.  It was amazing!!  Everyone loved it.  Thank you Vincenza for the starter recipe!!  I'm sure when we don't have homemade broth we will still be using this recipe with store bought.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My boyfriends eyes lit up after the first sip he took of this soup.  He said it was "awesome".
I didn't follow the advice of adding more vegetables, but will next time. 
Because I have a wheat intollerance, I used rice pasta broken up into small pieces.  I also cooked these seperately and added 5 minutes before serving.  
I didn't have 4 cans of chicken stock on hand, so I used 2 cans + a bouillon cube and water.  I wouldn't recommend a whole bouillon cube though, as mine turned out a little saltier than I would have liked.
I used fresh frozen basil, which I prefer to dried.
It took a little longer than the time stated (about an hour as opposed to half hour), however once you get the hang of the recipe, I think it would end up closer to half hour. 
All in all, a fantastic soup recipe.  5 stars!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
REMINDER: Good and bad reviews will vary upon ingredients used. I found the following to prove the best results. Simple Organic brand chicken stock at Kroger is good, if you don't already have your own. It smells good when I open the container and that is a big thing to me regarding chicken stock. 
Tips: No.1.The amount of chicken equals about 1 chicken breast, use salt and pepper with the chicken when prepping for the recipe. No.2. The amount of chicken stock is 58 ounces, or 7 and a fourth cups. No. 3 A food processor cuts the time in half, unless you buy the pre-chopped and sliced vegetables in the produce section of the store. Frozen may be acceptable. But as mentioned above, quality ingredients is key, so DO NOT USE canned vegetables in this recipe. Happy Cooking, everyone! :)

Display Name:
April

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm a beginner, never cooked much until I had my daughter. I was just using the recipe on the back of the Swanson broth container but decided I wanted to try a different flavor. I use a precooked rotisserie chicken from the grocery store& just tear it apart (& typically we snack on it too). I used leeks & omitted onion because I HATE chopping onions (also had carrots& celery). I was a bit nervous so I only used 1/4 teaspoon of the seasonings (I have a 1.5 yr old who just became a picky eater in the last 2 weeks- WTH?!). I also used pastini (little star noodles) because my daughter doesn't like the dumpling egg noodles we get (too big I think, but dad needs certain types of pasta/noodles because of a neurological disorder that makes his hands shake). I didn't sauté anything, just cut it up & cook the  out of it in the broth& seasonings, add chicken towards the end & simmer a bit, then finally the noodles. Made it during nap time for dinner later. 
I don't get all the reviews with suggestions to make it more difficult/complicated, they should just submit their own recipe as P.I.A. Chicken Soup. I also hate the "prep time" it's always way longer for me than what the recipe says (partly for not really knowing what I'm doing & partly because I usually have a screaming toddler hanging on me).

I am fairly new to cooking and this was the first chicken noodle soup recipe I found! Loved it, so yummy and soothing! I did tweak it a bit. I added a tad more butter, really just a smidge. text:
Made this last night.  Followed suggestions by Brown Sugar Girl.  Increased the veggies to 1C each, added 2 minced garlic cloves, increased the amount of noodles to 3 cups but cooked them separately and added to each bowl when serving.  Added a couple pinches of thyme.  I also cut 2 thighes into bite size pieces and browned a little with the veggies then added the broths & continued witht the recipe.  Saved cooking the chicken in a separate pot and it finished cooking in the broth.  The soup was DELICIOUS.  I will definitely make it again.  Thank you Maryvm for a great & easy soup.

text:
I made this soup exactly as written the first time and it was yummy the first night, but the second day the noodles absorbed all the liquid and I ate yummy chicken casserole. So the second time I made it I made the noodles on the side and just added them as needed. It is quick and even my 7 year old who refuses all soups will eat this with no problems. I also used this recipe for making my own broth the second time: www.eatingwell.com/recipes/easy_chicken_broth.html and it was also super easy.

text:
Wonderful recipe!  My one year old, husband and I all enjoy this at least once a week.  I only made a few changes based on some of the other reviews.  I throw the carrots in with the onion and celery in the butter.  I also add a clove of garlic, minced to the butter concoction.  I like to use 2 cups of whole wheat egg noodles per 6 servings.  I usually double or triple the recipe and freeze any remaining.  5 stars for sure!

text:
I just started cooking about a month ago and this was really easy to make and very yummy! I couldn't find veggie broth so I added extra chicken broth. Some other changes I made were: adding a little extra chicken and spices. Adding ANOTHER 14.5 oz can of chicken broth. I also cut the amount of onions in half since we are not big fans but I did want the taste. I used more noodles. I nearly doubled carrots bc I love them! I also added a little garlic powder, adobo and 2 chicken boullion cubes. It was very very very good! Next time I may add even more broth bc with all the additions I made to suit our large family, I noticed the amount of liquid boiled down into the ingredients. It would certainly still be classified as soup but... Haha!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/587227.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very quick and easy, and my husband absolutely loved it.  I did sautee the butter, garlic, onion, celery and carrots.  I then added bite-sized raw pieces of chicken along with the broth, basil, oregano, salt, pepper, and a few shakes of poultry seasoning and thyme.  I brought it to a boil and added uncooked gluten-free penne noodles to the boiling water and simmered for 20 minutes.  I understand why some people cook the noodles separately because my noodles absorbed all the broth (most of which was vegetable by the way since I had it on hand), so I ended up with a really delicious chicken soup pasta dish, and my husband said the noodles were really delicious because they absorbed all the broth.  I could have easily added more broth to make it soupier, but we actually really enjoyed it as a pasta dish.  Next time I'll add more broth though. I served with parmesan on top.

text:
This is one of those recipes that I will print for my recipe box.  I havent felt well for days and canned soup was just not cutting it and since I had left over rotisserie chicken (home made rotisserie) I figured why not.
I used everything EXCEPT the vegetable broth, and instead doubled the chicken broth content. I also added water as I used quite a bit of chicken and a VERY large stock pot, so that way the noodles would be covered.

It was simply delicious. Next time I'll cut back on the onion and will NOT add salt (the broth had plenty, I forgot) but it is definitely coming back to my kitchen, my kids DEVOURED it!

text:
I really enjoyed this recipe. It was soooo easy. I sauteed the chicken breast in cubes with basil, garlic, and onion powder on low. I used twice the amt of stock and used brown egg noodles. I used close to 3/4 tsp of oregano and basil. I was initially gonna add cream of chicken with herbs but found this was tasty and thick enough. I sauteed in butter but will try olive oil in future since I hardly ever cook with butter. My husband, King Finicky, loved it! I wasnt sure whether to simmer with top on or not so I put it on half way.

text:
This was so quick & easy!!  My fiance went hunting for the week & wanted something that was mild (most of my soups are spicy!) to keep in the crockpot so all they had to do was keep it on the warm setting & could eat on it as they came in for lunch/dinner.  He specifically requested chicken noodle soup so I tried this recipe...  His dad told him I need to make this soup again very soon!  They finished it off in the first day!    I used a whole rotessirie chicken & just peeled it off the bones.  I added 2 cloves of garlic about 3 minutes into cooking the onion & celery.  My grocery store was out of vegetable stock so I used 5 cans of chicken broth.  Other than that, I made it as is & it turned out incredible for how easy it was!!  This recipe will definitely be saved & made again & again!

text:
The best soup ever!  My family raved about it!  I made this today, tripling the recipe, but used my own chicken broth (along with canned vegetable broth) from the whole chicken I boiled and deboned yesterday (I even cut up my veggies yesterday as well to cut down on kitchen time today).  I also added chopped garlic and cream of chicken soup (not really for creaminess but for flavor and salt so I didn't need to sprinkle in much salt at all) but otherwise followed the recipe exactly.  Oh, I also sauteed all the veggies and garlic together, not just the celery and onion.  I will definitely be making this again and will one day try using all store bought broth when I don't have time to make my own.  This is definitely a good starter for people like me who have never made chicken noodle soup.

Display Name:
BirdieMama

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the best chicken noodle soup I have ever eaten!  I can't follow a recipe exactly for the life of me, so of course, I tweaked it a little, but it is incredible!  This is what I did:  Boiled four chicken thighs in 8 cups water until the meat fell off the bones, then cut the chicken into small pieces and discarded the bones.  Sauted all the veggies as suggested by Brown Sugar Girl.  I also threw in about one cup of frozen chopped spinach leaves for some extra "good green stuff" and iron!    Added 6 teaspoons chicken granules and the spices as recommended by Brown Sugar Girl to the water I boiled the chicken in and returned the water to a boil.  Cooked three packages of the cheapest, generic "Ramen" noodles I had in six cups of hot water in the microwave for five minutes.  Drained them and added them to the pot of chicken and broth along with all the veggies and simmered for about 5 minutes (that is all I could wait!).  I then had to go back and make another pot because it was so good that my husband and I literally finished off the first batch for LUNCH!  That time I didn't add any spinach because I had used all I had in the freezer in the first batch, but I tripled the carrots and celery.  YUMMY!    Really, really yummy soup that will definitely be on our weekly rotation!

text:
Update: This recipe does not freeze well.  Changed rating from 4 to 3 stars.  I'll probably stick with the canned stuff for this reason.  Original rating: This is an easy and quick recipe.  I didn't measure anything and it still came out great.  Here are my modifications (bear in mind I halved the recipe): Add more onion and noodles;  saute the onions, celery, and carrots in the butter until almost tender; use 1 can of 33% less sodium chicken broth, 1 can of regular chicken broth, and a 1/2 can of vegetable broth.  I hope this helps.

text:
This is outstanding soup! It's so easy to make, and not intimidating at all. Anyone can make this. This is definely becoming a stable recipe in our household. I doubled the batch, and followed the directions to a tee, except added double the chicken. I made the soup in a pot over the stove, then put it in a crock pot to keep Lo/warm. I took the suggestion of adding the noodles in last, and put them in a 1/2-1 hr before serving. This seemed to work well. I made it for dinner Halloween night as we were having another family over, and I thought it would be quick and easy to serve with good bread. Little did I know everyone wanted seconds, even thirds for some and I  received rave reviews. There was little to spare after the four adults and 5 kids ate it. It also hit the spot after coming in from the cold from trick or treaking, everyone warmed up with a cup of soup. Delicious!

text:
Love this recipe!  So easy to whip together.  I bought a rotissere chicken and used that for the soup.  Although I think this is a good quick way to get chicken in the soup, it felt apart and was really stringy and i think a bit overcooked.  I will try to make the time to do my own chicken next time.  I did use chicken bouliion instead of broth and while I think this added flavor it also added salt.  I did not add any other salt and still felt it was borderline too salty.  Next time I'll use more water with the boullion.  We LOVED this soup.  I doubled it and it was nice to have for a couple of meals.  This will be a Fall fave in our house!

We loved this soup! Yes, I agree it is going to be only as good as the broth you use, as someone mentioned...so use good broth! I added a teaspoon of Penzey's chicken soup base, and based on the other reviews, added chopped garlic and sauteed all the vegetables together (only 1/4 cup celery). Usually I make chicken soup with a whole chicken, making my own stock.  When my daughter came home with a cold though, I had to make due with what I had on hand.  I expected this to be a somewhat mediocre soup, good enough for someone who couldn’t taste that well.  This was a surprisingly good soup!  I sautéed the carrots and raw chicken chunks along with the onions and celery.  The vegetable broth made the canned chicken broth have a much more interesting flavor.  As always, I cooked the noodles separately and added them to the soup as we ate it.  I will make this soup again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was very good however I made a few changes. I made this in the slow cooker as it is the easiest for me on busy days. I used olive oil in place of the butter and a 16oz. bag of Reames frozen noodles. (We like the frozen noodles better as they have a chewy texture that reminds us of homemade noodles!) After cooking the vegetables and chicken in the olive oil, I threw everything in the slow cooker for approx. 3 hours on high. Add the noodles the last 45-60 minutes of the cooking time and enjoy.  These noodles will really soak up the broth so if you like a more brothy consistency you may need to add a little more chicken broth.

One of my very favorite chicken soups. Important to use homemade chicken broth from the cooked chicken. I season my broth with Lawry's seasoning salt, pepper, and a little powdered garlic while simmering the chicken. I also think the additional vegetable broth gives it a great flavor. (I use Swanson's vegetable broth in a box). Double vegetables and add more chicken to this recipe! Top it off with freshly grated Parmesan cheese and dig in!

text:
Quick and easy is right.  This soup is excellent. I made some of the changes suggested by other reviewers:  I upped the chicken to 12 oz., egg noodles to 2-1/2 c. and added garlic.  I am a salt person but I thought this was borderline too salty so next time I will use 2 cans "low sodium" chicken broth and 2 regular.  I didn't add any salt "to taste" as the recipe suggested. I used roasted chicken from a whole roasted chicken... the kind you buy hot at the market.  I think that added extra flavor.  Also next time I am going to increase the onion to 3/4 c. and the celery to 1 c.  The whole family loved this soup.  I think I will have some of the leftovers for lunch!!! Yum!

This soup was fantastic!  I read the recipe wrong initially and only purchased one can of chicken broth, so I had to use bouillan cubes.  It tasted so good I made the recipe again the next week but used all canned broth.  The broth definitely made the soup more rich than the cubes did, but it was nice to know that the cubes will work(and taste just fine) in a pinch!  I also added a pinch of rosemary and a touch of garlic salt (instead of regular salt) to the soup giving it a nice flavor.  My husband tries new recipes tentatively, and he approved this one!

text:
My daughter loves canned chicken noodle soup so I thought I would try this one.  I made a few changes - more onions & celery, added garlic.  I only had 2 cans of broth so filled in with water/bouillon.  I wanted to add a cream of chicken soup to add a little thickness but only had potato so I used that.

The biggest difference was that I didn't have fresh chicken so I used canned.  I had never used canned chicken before but it worked.  After adding the basil and oregano the flavor really filled out.  I thought it was a very good soup. My daughter didn't like the veggies so next time I'll strain them out before adding the chicken and noodles.  Thanks for the recipe and all the reviews.

text:
I was really impressed with this very easy and comforting soup. It tasted like I had been cooking it all day, when in fact I was tired from picking pumpkins at our local farm that day! A few things I changed simply for personal preference. I doubled the celery  and used a little bit more butter to saute the carrots and celery together. Omitted the onions but used onion powder in it's place along with a little garlic powder. I used a 15oz. box of low sodium chicken broth (all I had on hand) and used 3/4 of a rotissere chicken.
This is my new favorite chicken noodle soup and I got a "better than my Jewish mother's" from my hubby!

I wanted chicken noodle soup because I have a bad sinus infection. I do not like canned soup and wanted to cook my own. As usual I turned to Allrecipes and found this one. 

This was my very first time making homemade chicken noodle soup. text:
Great easy soup. I sautéed the carrots with onion,celery and 1 small can of mushrooms. Add about 3 qts of either canned chicken stock or a mixture of chicken and vegetable stock. 
I added 1/2 lb of leftover rotisserie chicken and 1 cup of frozen mixed vegetables. Simmer 20 min.  Add  12 ounces of cooked noodles. Add 1/4 tsp fresh ground pepper. Simmer 5 minutes. 
Top with a few Italian seasoned croutons and a little Parmesan cheese.       Yum

I absolutely loved this recipe! I read the reviews and did what brown sugar girl said and sautéd the garlic, carrots, celery and onion together. I didn't have veggie stock or broth so I cooked my chicken breasts in the chicken stock and seasoned it with a little bit of basil, oregano, seasoning salt and garlic powder. I also followed another reviewers tip and didn't cook my pasta in it, I boiled my pasta separately and added it to my soup myself. My husband and I both loved this recipe so much it will be used in my household from this day forward! Please try it you will love it!

text:
An easy chicken soup! My review is more for my own reference when I make it again... I used 3 chicken breasts halves (~ 2lbs.) cubed, 1 box chicken broth plus 1 box vegetable broth, 5 diced carrots, 4 diced celery stalks, 1 M onion, minced, 1/2 tsp salt, 1/4 tsp pepper, 1/2 tsp oregano, 1/2 tsp basil, 1/2 tsp parsley. I sautéed the veggies in butter until slightly tender ~10min then added all the other ingredients and let cook on low in the crock pot. Cooked the noodles separately.  Very good! I will make this again.

I had never made chicken soup before,  and my friend's mom passed away and I wanted to made something for the family. They were all so happy that I made this for them. I have made this 3 times in the past week so far and everyone that has tried it loves it!  I had never heard of adding basil and oregano to chicken soup but it really gives it a wonderful flavor. city:

region:

country:

text:
Great recipe! Made a few changes but nothing major, mainly just followed the advice many others have given about this recipe. Upped the onions, celery and carrots to about 2 cups each. Sauted the onions, celery and carrots with garlic, in extra virgin olive oil and butter. Used the meat from a whole rotisserie chicken. Used 1 tsp of dried oregano and basil each. Also added 1/4 tsp of thyme powder. Added pepper. I used 4 cans of low sodium chicken broth, 1 can of vegetable broth. Brought to a boil then reduced heat and simmered for 20 minutes uncovered. Added rice noodles after 5 minutes of simmering and stirred every couple of minutes. It turned out tasting and smelling fantastic! My wife and two year old son both enjoyed it, and my sister-in-law said she wished she hadn't of just eaten before she came over. With the changes I made it came right up to 3 quarts before it reduced a little from cooking. Also, I thought it tasted so good it didn't even need any salt! Which is saying a lot for me.

Display Name:
pawprints

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5880798.jpg
city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My boyfriend said this was the best chicken noodle soup I've ever made.  Usually when I made chicken soup, 
 I make completely homemade broth, so this was surprising to hear!!!   I think the addition of a can of veggie broth was what made the real difference in this recipe.  I never would have thought to do that.  It seemed to brighten or enhance the flavor very subtly.  I used Swanson brand for both broths to avoid MSG, and the chicken broth was the fat free, 33% less sodium kind.   I  used leftover meat from a rotisserie chicken and also added a little garlic with the onion, and added a bay leaf while it was simmering, but otherwise followed the recipe exactly.  I used carrots straight from the garden.  I will use this recipe from now on.  It certainly was much less time, less work, and we both liked it better, so it's win-win.  P.S.  It was even better the next day.

text:
This is a very nice "quick" chicken soup that's better than canned by far.  So that's my rating.  I usually don't write reviews. After reading the reviews already written I just had to make a comment.  I was amazed to see how many people start out by saying the soup is great and then go about giving you their own, completely different, version.  I thought the idea of reviews was to rate the recipe at hand.  If you want to write your own recipe submit it as your own work and let people rate you.

text:
Very good! My husband, 4 year olds and 19 month old loved it! I took the advice of fellow reviewers and used uncooked, chopped boneless thighs. I sautéed the veggies in butter, lightly seasoned the thighs before cooking and boiled the noodles separately. I will definitely make this again! I used 6 thighs, 4 carrots, 4 stalks of celery, 2 cloves of garlic, 1/2 cup onions , 64 oz of chicken broth, 14.5 oz of veg broth and 3/4 bag of extra wide egg noodles. This will feed my family of 5 for two days if not more.

text:
I was looking for an easy to make Chicken Noodle Soup recipe. I have been cooking for years, but oddly have never made chicken noodle soup! This was a quick and easy base recipe. I did make a few additions because it was quite bland. I sauteed the onions, garlic, celery, and carrots for about 10 minutes then added the broth and spices. It was kind of dull at this point. I then added 1/2 tsp celery seed, 1/2 tsps onion powder, and 1 tsp chicken boullion (and of course, salt and pepper) and that made a huge difference. It was really tasty and everyone liked it :)

text:
Yesterday when I made this for dinner I gave it 2 stars . I made it by cooking just 1 breast in the broth, shredding the chicken, and then adding everything until it was soft. Seemed logical. But it came out rather bland. Maybe I've been spoiled by my mom's soup. But this one didn't do it for me. I said I would not make again.
Now, the next day I am kicking this up to 3 stars and saying I will make again with the understanding that this is BASE soup. Next time I will use moister rotisserie chicken meat, brand name Swanson broth instead of generic, and add more spices and salt. 
I can only give this 3 stars as I don’t think the recipe is good enough “as is”.

text:
This soup was amazing. I sautéed the onion, celery, and garlic cloves until tender. I love onions and garlic so I used a medium onion and 4 garlic cloves. I used all chicken broth. If you're using Swanson, I use reduced sodium. I added the carrots to 32 ozs of broth and boiled until tender (20 minutes). I then added meat from a whole rotisserie chicken, the remaining broth, the sautéed vegetables and the noodles to the pot and boiled until the noodles were tender. I added a little Zatarins creole seasoning for added flavor. Soooo good! I will never buy store bought soup again.

.

userID:
7426065
Display Name:
49flavours
isPro:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
We have this at least twice a month and I am convinced it heals me when I'm sick. I strongly recommend you cook the chicken separately because it's just too hard and flavorless when boiled. Here's what I've found that really improves this recipe: Marinate 1 lb chicken in a little Worcestershire, then pressure cook it (or any way you have to make tender, juicy chicken). Saute a whole bag of carrots, 1 onion and 4-5 celery stalks. Give the carrots a head start. Add chopped garlic or garlic powder and other spices you like (we like thyme and pepper). Add broth, bring to a boil, cover and simmer 20 minutes. Then add the chicken. Also, it's very important to cook the egg noodles separate and keep them separate until serving your bowl or they get mushy. The best chicken soup!!

text:
With my slight modifications, I'm rating this a 5 star. I've never cooked chicken noodle soup in my life so I'm thankful for this recipe giving me a base to work with. I used 1 cup carrots, 1 cup onions, and 1 cup of celery. I followed other reviewer's advice and sauteed the veggies in garlic and butter. I added the broth. All chicken broth, cause that's all I had. I used 3 chicken breasts, cubed, and dumped that in the broth. Bring to a boil and then let it simmer for 30 minutes. Then I added the egg noodles for another 10 minutes at the end. Delicious!! A lot of the seasoning stuck to the chicken and gave it a lot of flavor. This soup definitely hit the spot. The entire family loved it!

text:
I only review recipes that I like. Its that good!
I followed some tips from other reviewers, boiling the chicken breast in chicken broth oregeno poultry seasoning and basil, remove it cut/shred it and then replace. I did that early in the day or can be done the night before just cover the pot and store in the frig. You can also precook the chopped celery and carrots in melted butter and garlic. Throw them in the pot and store. Then when dinner time rolls around all you gotta do is cook your noodles, boil the soup and make whatever else. I asked my husband and three kids (7,11 and 9) what they thought. My 9 yr old exclaimed "you made this yourself?" (not from a can?!) the 11 yr old went for seconds and so did my husband. So all in all everybody ate it and didn't complain. I made biscuts with the soup, but I'm sure garlic bread, french bread or grilled cheese sandwiches would be great too.

userID:

Display Name:
MmmmILoveSweets

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a pretty good soup. Best of all, VERY EASY!! MY MODIFICATIONS: 1.) Added 2 cloves of minced garlic when sauteing the onions and celery. 2.) Used a whole rotisserie chicken from the Costco (and those bad boys are BIG) so roughly 1lb. of chicken in the end, 3.) Used 1c. of every vegetable, instead of the recommended 1/2 cup, 4.) Used nearly 1 tsp., instead of 1/2 tsp., of all of the spices called for in the recipe (minus the salt! which I always add sparingly). 5.) I also did NOT use low-sodium chicken broth, as I find that soups just don't have enough flavor when you use that. So I stuck with the regular stuff. 6.) And finally, I cooked the noodles on the side and then added them when the soup was finished simmering (about 2min before I dished it out into bowls). MY VERDICT: I'd definitely make this recipe again!! It's easy and you can pretty much throw whatever you want in here for a delicious and hearty meal.

text:
This recipe is a good recipe to start with if you want to make chicken soup quickly or use up left over chicken. What's great about this is that I can double up on the vegetables without having to add additional stock or broth to it.

Aside from doubling the vegetables, I did make a few changes to fit our taste. I sauted the carrots with the onion and celery. I also added sliced fennel bulb. I also replaced the basil with thyme and also used parsley.

text:
Not bad (although my vote goes to Steve Grooms' chicken noodle soup). I've been battling a terrible head cold all weekend and my hubs thinks he might be catching what I have.... Chicken soup was exactly what we needed! While I appreciate how simple this was to prepare (especially considering I was too sick to cook), this just didn't cut it for us flavor-wise. I even added thyme, poultry seasoning, a bay leaf and some fresh minced garlic (which I sauteed with my onions / celery), hoping to impart a tad more flavor. Because I didn't have any cooked chicken handy, I purchased a rotisserie chicken instead. I tossed the ENTIRE bird (along with the pan juices) into my pot with everything else and simmered as directed. I then removed the carcass and added the shredded meat back to my soup. Even with these changes, my soup was still a bit on the bland side. :( NOTE: Boil your pasta SEPARATELY and add it to each bowl upon serving (this will prevent the pasta from swelling). For a quick fix, this is fine (this is definitely better than canned soup!), but I definitely won't be replacing my stand-by recipe with this one. Thanks anyways, MARYVM. :-)

text:
The BEST chicken noodle soup ever!  Made it for my 90-year old parents who are very fussy and they couldn't get enough!  Used a rotisserie chicken and spaghetti which I cut up in small pieces as they're easier for them to manage vs wide egg noodles which slip off the spoon.  Substituted parsley for the basil, left out the oregano and added a bay leaf.  Used Kitchen Basics brand for the broth which we like best and omitted the vegtable broth.  This is the ONLY chicken noodle soup recipe I will use from now on!

text:
Excellent!!! My boyfriend was feeling a bit under the weather & had a bunch of rotisserie chicken leftover, that he was complaining was going to go to waste, so I was looking for a quick and easy soup recipe to kill 2 birds with 1 stone and fix him some soup to make him feel better and use the chicken and I FOUND it!  This was great!  I also added a clove of garlic and I also sauteed the celery and carrots in the butter with the onion and garlic. I also used more chicken & noodles than called for, as he wanted a chunkier soup. He loved it & I think he'll deliberately buy too much rotisserie chicken in the future, just so he can have this soup, again!

Really yummy and very easy!  I followed the recipe but did add 64 ounces of chicken broth because that's what I had (and I found it wasn't too much).  I did add a bit of sea salt as my husband likes this soup salty (yep, ruined by years of salty canned soup!...which no more canned for us...).  Delish! I cooked the noodles separately as advised and froze half the recipe without the noodles and put the cooked noodles in the soup I saved for us to eat tonight.  I will be making this a lot.

text:
Very easy and delicious too. I used boneless skinless thighs though because that's what I had on hand (plus I think it stays moist and adds flavor, IMO) and didn't use vegetable broth as I didn't have any on hand. I added a little bit of diced sweet potato and a handful of peas to get in more veggies (mostly for my toddler) and instead of using the dried herbs, salt and pepper, I used salt free 21 Seasoning Salute from Trader Joe's since it has tons of flavor and there's enough sodium in the chicken broth. Yum!

text:
Phenomenal soup!  I'm a personal trainer and nutritionist so I went ahead and tripled up on the veggies.  To boost the healthful side of the soup I added 4 cloves minced garlic (sauteed with the veggies prior to adding the broth and spices), instead of butter I used 2 tablespoons olive oil, store bought rotisserie chicken (skin removed), and substituted egg noodles for whole grain penne pasta.  AHmazing!  If you like spicy, try a drizzle of Siracha.  Sounds funny, but it really makes the soup pop with a smidge of heat.

Display Name:
sbrossi

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1075987.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely my favorite 'homemade' chicken noodle soup! I've made this over a dozen times already and will never look for a new recipe. This is better than ANY chicken soup I've tried to make using a whole chicken from scratch. (1) I use Costco's rotisserie chicken and pull it apart while it's perfectly warm; that makes it so easy to get the perfect sized larger chunks of chicken like I love in homemade soup. My kids always love it. (2) I like to double the recipe and use ONE WHOLE rotisserie; that seems to be the perfect proportion of all ingredients to me. (3) I also use only chicken broth (no veggie broths) just because that's what I always stock in my pantry. (4) And I've discovered that the only noodles that do the trick and hold up in leftovers are the original Anthony's Extra Wide Egg Noodles.

I made this for my sick boyfriend and liked it just as much as he did! He has bronchitis and his throat hurts too much to even drink water but he said this didn't hurt at all going down.  The recipe made enough for our dinner and for at least 3 more meals for the sick kid.

But anyway, I made a few modifications.  I am allergic to a lot of vegetables so I used 5 cans of chicken broth instead of using 1 can of vegetable broth.  Also, I replaced the carrots with potatoes (two small potatoes).  I just cut them up small and threw them in to the pot before bringing it to a boil and they were perfectly mushy at the end of the 20 minutes.

I added more basil and oregano than the recipe called for (probably 2 tsps of each) because I like a lot of flavor.

I added the egg noodles before bringing the broth to a boil but next time I will probably wait to add the noodles until after it boils because they were a bit too mushy at the end.  

I didn't add any salt "to taste" because the broth made this salty enough.  Not too salty though!

This is a fantastic recipe and going in my favorites for sure!

text:
This is the best chicken noodle soup recipe!  I have tried several other recipes that I didn't like that much.  I added garlic to the onion/celery/carrot mix.  I also added a dash of thyme and about half a teaspoon of parsley with the other herbs.  I let the soup (minus the noodles) simmer for several hours then cooked up the noodles and added them right before serving.  I served the soup with some homemade french bread.  It is a great soup recipe for when you're sick (which my daughter was) or for a cold day meal...thank you for an excellent recipe!

A great meal for families on the go.  I have made this twice now, once quickly on the stove and once all day in a crock pot and enjoyed it both times.  I like it more like stew so I add a whole pre-cooked chicken and lots of veggies (green beans and peas work well too).  My only recommendation is to use at least some unsalted broth with the pre-cooked chicken or it comes out pretty salty.  Thanks for the recipe!

text:
So easy & yummy. Experimented with using canned chicken - not so tasty. Better to use the Kirkland flash frozen, no defrost boneless, skinless chicken thighs. I followed the pkge directions to cook those chicken thighs, cooled it and then cubed to add to the soup. Better to cook everything except the noodles first. I added a mix of cut spaghetti & mini farfalle noodles towards the last 20 min of cooking. Cut the carrots & celery smaller to appeal to the younger kids. Tasted great!

I can't tell you how much this makes my boyfriend feel better when I make this for him whenever he's sick. He absolutely HATES veggies, but in this recipe, he gobbles them all right up! Even the carrots! Thank you so much for this recipe. text:
Excellent, fast and easy.   CHANGES I MADE : I didn't have any broth so I added 2 chicken bouillon cubes and one veggie bouillon cube to the noodles while I precooked them. I did not drain the noodles, I poured in the water and noodles into the saute pot. I added a can of chicken breast meat due to ease and I was out of chicken breasts.. also I followed other reviewers suggestions to saute garlic, celery, onions and carrots, I did this while boiling the noodles poured it all together added spices and voila! Done so fast and it tasted like it had cooked all day. YUM

text:
I made this for my sick boyfriend and it was delicious and soothing!  A few changes...I did not cook the veggies in butter to make it healthier, plus some people posted how mushy everything got.  I just cooked some chicken tenders in 2 cans of the chicken broth, added the seasoning at this point...then cut the veggies up while it was cooking.  Then I added the veggies and noodles and shredded the chicken (the chicken tasted great after cooking in the broth and seasonings).  Cooked on medium for 20 mins and everything was perfect!

I made this for dinner tonight with some leftover roasted chicken breast and it was excellent. I did not use the vegetable broth, just the 4 cans of chicken broth. I used 8 oz of frozen noodles instead of the egg noodles and they cooked up great in 20 -25 mins. in the soup. I also followed other reviewers suggestions and sautéed the carrots along with the other vegetables and added 1 clove of minced garlic. I had some fresh parsley and rosemary and I added a bit of both just before serving. Truly a great and easy soup.

I do a lot of cooking and had never tried chicken noodle soup.  I followed the advice of the other reviews and sauteed the carrots, celery, onion together with some minced garlic and butter. Then i added the already cooked chicken and mixed it in for some flavor then added the broth. I didn't want soggy noodles so I cooked them separately and put them to the side, but still was stupid and put them in with the broth for 10 minutes or more before serving and they were soggy anyways...ha ha. I also felt like it needed more salt...so I gave it a 3 for now. I am trying it again next week with more salt...maybe some boullon and probably more garlic and I'll see if I like it better. The way I made it, it was just ok...

text:
Followed others' recommendations and did the following - sauteed garlic, onion, celery and carrots in butter. Only then did I add the rest of the ingredients in the pot (except the noodles) and brought to a boil, covered and simmered 20 min. Cooked up the egg noodles separately then added to the pot (after draining)- simmered an additional 10 min. I had also added 1 can of cream of chicken soup to add some creaminess. Among the best chicken noodle soups we've ever had.

text:
I had a cold and don't like eating canned soups when I can avoid it. I made this, and it was very comforting and easy to eat. I didn't have any celery and used 1/3 tsp celery salt rather than fresh celery. It came out good still. Next time I would definitely use fresh celery and add about 1 tsp salt. I also pre-cooked the chicken, and I thought it was unnecessary. Throwing the raw cubed chicken in with the rest of the broth would have been just as good.

text:
This is a great simple recipe for a healthy and tasteful soup! My only change is adding a garlic clove in with the onion and saute. I also doubled the celery and carrot as I like the vegetables. It is great with canned broth and even better with homemade broth. Just stick some chicken bones in the crockpot with onion, garlic, seasonings, carrots, celery and parsley. Cook for 8 hours and strain. Either way is still yummy. My kids absolutely love it!

text:
Incredible flavor especially for a cold winter's day & flexible enough to personally tweak!! Very easy though I simmered mine for a couple hours (the house smelled wonderful). I sautéed onions, celery & a clove of garlic in olive oil, then added the cooked chicken. I dumped this in the soup stock pot with the broth (definitely include the can of vegetable broth)& added the suggested seasonings plus a pinch of poultry seasoning & tarragon. Next, I sautéed the carrots until tender & added them.  About 30 minutes before serving, I added the pasta. Next time I'll try this with whole wheat pasta  --I'll bet it would be delicious!  Thanks for sharing an excellent recipe.

text:
This is super easy and super good.  I use one whole chopped onion and add lots of extra carrots to make the soup heartier.  Make sure you use the veggie broth as it really enhances the flavor -- to me it makes it taste more authentic and scratch, rather than a quick recipe.  I also just add 2 whole boneless chicken breasts with 10 minutes left and simmer about 10 minutes until the chicken shreds easily between 2 forks.  Finally, a tsp of thyme or curry powder depending on the mood is a nice add

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1897675.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was fantastic! I made a few changes based on what I had on hand plus I needed it to be gluten free. For the chicken I cooked chicken breasts in a crock pot with salt/fresh cracked pepper/poultry seasoning/couple whole cloves and a couple bay leaves. I left it to cool over night in the fridge in the pot which makes the breast really tender. (I did up a large pot full for a number of meals) I used Earth Balance margarine since we can't do dairy. I didn't have chicken or veggie broth so I used the broth from the crock pot after it had separated. I added 2-3 times the basil and oregano called for and for the noodles I used Trader Joes Rice Sticks traditional Thai style pasta broken into pieces about 1 inch each. It came out perfect and even my super picky child liked it.

country:
None
text:
This is an awesome recipe and I did make changes - but very minor!  I sauteed the onions, celery, carrots and 2 cloves of garlic in the butter.  Then I added the chicken stock - low sodium. Then I threw in an entire rotisserie chicken and let it simmer for 20 minutes or so.  I added the basil, oregano and salt and pepper.  Then I removed the chicken and then added the chicken pieces back in - threw out the bones etc.  After simmering for a little bit longer I added the egg noodles to the soup and turned up the heat to a boil.  My husband who is pretty darn picky LOVED this chicken noodle soup!  I love a one pot meal and this was delish - next time I will definitely add vegetable broth as I think that will make it even better!!

text:
Good stuff!!!  I tweaked it a little-bit by using rotisserie chicken that I bought from the deli at my local grocery store.  I also add a large can of cream of chicken soup, a few cubes of chicken bouillon, Accent seasoning, poultry seasoning, thyme, bay leaves (filter thru a tea bag), onion powder, minced garlic & chopped red bell pepper which I sauteed with the celery and onion.  I chose to use frozen mixed veg. which had carrots in the bag of course and I added them about 10 minutes after adding the broth to the onion, red bell pepper, & minced garlic. I added the noodles about 5 minutes before it was done to keep them from being overcooked.  It turned out great!!!

Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:
2009-03-04T08:37:23.3
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1774271
Display Name:
BRIDGET
isPro:
False
followersCount:
1
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
19
favoritesCount:
91
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/206389.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made several adjustments to this recipes, hence the 4 star rating. I used an entire 48oz box of Swanson's MSG free low sodium chicken broth, and 2 Herb-ox msg free chicken boullion and 4 cups of water. I sauted the onions, celery, and carrots in some olive oil rather than the butter. I used a rotisserie chicken and picked off all the meat (except the breasts, I saved them for another meal this week) and just dumped that into the pot with the veggies and the broth. I let it come to a boil then let it simmer for about an hour. I didn't have whole bay leaves so I used someone else's tip from A/R and emptied a tea bag and added my bay leaf pieces and let that stew with everything. I removed it right before serving. I used egg noodles and cooked them in a seperate pot so they wouldn't get all soggy. I can't wait for leftovers for lunch and dinner!! Even the sick DBF liked it, though he only ate a few bites he said it was good. I didn't add any other spices except for the bay leaves. No salt, or pepper or the other spices the recipe called for. Didn't want DBF to not eat it because it was too spiced up.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674155.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I used this recipe as a base recipe for this: I bought a greek flavored rotisserie chicken, took all the meat off the bones, and then made a stock out of the bones by simmering them in water for about 30-45 minutes. I used all the meat in the soup, and also added a generous pinch of marjoram to compliment the generous pinches of oregano and basil. I don't really closely measure ingredients for soups (obviously), so I ended up using about 3 stocks of celery, 1/2 of a big yellow onion, maybe 1-1 1/2 cups chopped carrots, and 3-4 cloves chopped garlic. I didn't add noodles this time, but may in the future. I would agree that the vegetable broth is KEY. I will make this again and again!!

Display Name:
Cathy Magestro

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5737870.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this soup over the weekend it was super easy and my husband and 13 year old son loved it (so did I).  I did modify the soup based on some of the other reviews though.  This is what I did to make it my own.  I used 2-32 ounce cans of chicken stock and 1-32 ounce can of vegetable stock.  I also used a whole bag of celery hearts and one pound of carrots (we like a lot of veggies), I also added about 6 small potatoes cubed.  I too used a whole rotissarie chicken, skinned it and de-boned it.  I skipped the oregeno but added the basil, pepper and garlic salt (no regular salt).  I used about a half of stick of butter and sauted all of my veggies in a big pot and when I thought they were getting somewhat soft, I added them to broth with the chicken and let that go for about 30 minutes.  The veggies got nice and soft.  I cooked my pasta on the side and did not add to the soup.  The longest part of the entire soup was the chopping of the veggies.  This was so easy and delicious!  Enjoy.

text:
I'm not a big fan of canned soups but dislike making homemade soup because it can be very time consuming. This recipe is not only super easy but also super tasty!! I used 1 32-ounce box of College Inn Rotisserie Chicken Broth.  In addition to the ingredients listed, I added a pinch each of white & black pepper, 1 tsp thyme, a couple pinches of poultry seasoning and some parsley flakes. Instead of egg noodles, I used 1/4 c. of pastina which are teeny-tiny pasta stars. I used Perdue Short Cuts grilled chicken which is super easy because the chicken is precooked/sliced.  All you have to do is dice it up into small pieces and throw it into the broth. This recipe rocks!!!

text:
This is a delicious, easy recipe. I used light butter instead of regular, and you couldn't tell a difference. I also added some garlic powder and extra basil and oregano (I love my spices!), which tasted great. 

I used cubed chicken breast, which I cooked in the broth. This made the soup a little cloudy, but I didn't care - it still tasted wonderful and made great leftovers! I also used whole wheat egg noodles - I felt really great about making such a tasty, yet nutritious soup for my family.

text:
when i make soup, i like to make LOADS and i like my soup super chunky!  So i used this recipe as a guide.  I sauteed one and a half medium chopped onion and a couple cloves of garlic.  Used two whole celery hearts, a whole bag of carrots, two thirty-something ounce boxes of chicken broth and one thirty-something ounce veg. broth, a whole rotisserie chicken hand shredded and almost a whole bag of egg noodles.  Seasoned as suggested in the recipe.  Sounds like a lot but it made a super hearty soup that lasted me, my sister, and boyfriend DAYS!! Really yummy and great for a cold day. definitely a keeper, thanks!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
sauteed 1 c each of diced onions, carrots, and celery with 1 tsp. garlic in 1 tbsp butter. chopped 2 uncooked chicken breasts and threw in with broth, 1/2 tsp each of basil, oregano, and poultry seasoning. 1/4 tsp thyme. shook salt and garlic powder over. bring to a boil and then reduce to simmer for 20 minutes. once simmering, start boiling second pot. after 12 minutes, add 3 c noodles and boil for 8 minutes. drain noodles and add to other pot. simmer for 10 more minutes.

https://smittenkitchen.com/2015/01/my-ultimate-chicken-noodle-soup/

text:
I thought this tasted 4 star, my husband 5 star. It's very easy to make. I cooked my chicken almost all the way through before putting it in the pot. I cooked my onions and carrots with some garlic and ginger as well as the butter. I had no celery. I was short on chicken broth, so I had to use chicken bullion cubes. They worked as a nice substitute. Don't skimp on the chicken broth, cause that will make a difference in how the soup tastes.

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2008-02-24T13:42:56.677
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
2074873
Display Name:
Joni
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614248.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
First time I've made soup.  My kids LOVE chicken noodle soup and I'm trying to serve them healthier foods instead of convenience.  I read the reviews and changed it a little.  My husband who loves the scratch soup that he makes and is more of a "chef" than I am said it was awesome.  My 7yo loved it.  My 10yo isn't home yet but if the 7yo loved it, more than likely he will.  I changed it by adding a little minced garlic in the sautee.  I used 4 C ready-made chicken broth and 4 C chicken bouillon.  Sauteed the carrots with the other veggies, plus cut raw chicken into the sautee and sprinkled the spices over that instead of with the broth.  I also goofed and used thyme instead of oregano (looked at the container wrong) so not sure how it would be with the oregano.  Used whole wheat Heartland spaghetti noodles (only whole wheat noodles my kids will eat) and no added salt (there's plenty in the broth).  Next time I will cook the carrots a bit before I sautee them to make them more tender, and I want to try olive oil instead of butter (my husband suggests just sauteeing in bouillon as another alternative to lower the fat).  This will be a new staple around here instead of boxed or canned soup - thank you!

My husband and I love this recipe!  It is very easy to make and is great for a quick dinner.  When I make it, I saute some minced garlic and the carrots along with the onions and celery. A very versatile and tasty recipe. I was looking for a way to use some cooked brown rice I had leftover so substituted for noodles. city:

None
country:
None
text:
I give this recipe 5 Stars! It was delicious! I varied alittle but took from it what it basically was along with some of the other viewers ideas. My family was sick and I used what I had in the house. Needless to say...Delish! and all gone! I browned the onion in the margarine along with a small amount of chopped up lettuce for flavor since I didnt have celery. (this almost melts away in cooking but tastes similiar) I used a whole chicken on the bone with about 8 cups of water to 3 boullion cubes. I also used 1/8 - 1/4 of a box of ditallini pasta because I didnt have egg noodles or rice. And like one other viewer I used basil, oregano, salt, pepper, garlic powder, poultry seasoning and thyme. I put all the chicken pieces in the pot whole, covered it and After about 20-30 the chicken was cooked. I removed it from the pot, took it off the bone, and returned the chicken pieces to the soup. I had made the pasta seperate, so I added it to the soup and served it hot, sprinkled with grated cheese! YUM!

text:
This is simple & delicious!  Of course I changed a few things.  I like more spice so I added 2 cloves garlic when sauteeing the veggies, 1/2 teaspoon celery salt, 1/4 teaspoon poultry seasoning & lots of black pepper.  I didn't have any vegetable broth so I used an envelope of dry vegetable soup mix & added 2 cups of water.  Since I had left over turkey from Thanksgiving I used that instead of chicken & I also had left over rice so used rice instead of noodles.  Tossed in a handful of peas & served with some hot rolls & a salad.  It was great for a snowy winter night in Iowa.
