photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/121.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was the first chicken soup I've ever made and it was easy and delicious.
The only thing I did differently was cook the chicken with the onions and celery. I then added the carrots several minutes later, as someone else suggested, to help make them softer. I also cut the carrots very small. I also cooked the egg noodles separetly. I noticed other people chose not to add the vegetable soup, but I think the vegetable soup was what made it a unique broth and I would recommened it if you are making this for the first time.
Thanks so much for this recipe, excellent!!! :)

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/54.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very tasty basic recipe - however, I did make a few changes, based on personal preference and availability - Other family members do not like oregano, so I reluctantly left it out. I didn't have any celery, so substituted a few shakes of celery seed. I added one fourth cup of minced green bell pepper, which I sauteed along with the onions, in addition to three minced garlic cloves. I also used all chicken broth, but next time I will make sure to have some vegetable broth on hand - sounds good! And, I used two cups of noodles. As other reviewers have mentioned, the prep time was a bit longer than expected, so I am going to chop up my desired vegetables in appropriate amounts and freeze. With leftover or store bought cooked chicken this soup will really be a breeze! - Don't omit the basil, it really adds to the flavor!

text:
I recently became very ill and didn't want to eat anything, not even my favorite foods.  And with my mom away I have to come up with the daunting task of cooking soup by myself.  So I found this recipe, followed the directions except used half a small whole chicken, cooked for 30 minutes longer, added a bit more water and boiled the pasta on the side.  Just had my first taste and it is incredible.  A wonderful comfort food full of italy like flavor, far fresher than any store bought canned junk, and with the added water not too salty for the sick.  And note, the oregano and basil make this dish.  Do what I did and drag yourself to the store if you have to.  You won't regret it!  Vin you're a lifesaver.

text:
Great recipe!  I am a vegetarian and even made this with ease for my sick boyfriend...thank goodness for the cooked cube chicken!  I took others' suggestions and used 1 can of cream of chicken soup, and 2 boxes of organic chicken broth (also lower in sodium). Sauteed the carrots with the celery and substituted scallions for onions, which I added with the broth & chicken.  Added the egg noodles half-way through cooking time. Turned out great (although I didn't actually taste it)! My boyfriend LOVED it-- ate two huge bowls--and he's somewhat picky. Great simple semi-homemade recipe!

dateLastModified:
2006-08-31T03:44:13.59
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
2022864
Display Name:
Jenny E.
isPro:
False
followersCount:
9
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
24
favoritesCount:
156
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/51288.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This soup was awesome!!! I changed a few things though. I bought canned sliced carrots (they are softer and they didn't get mushy), I finely chopped the celery before I sauted them with the onions. I did take the advice of a previous review and substituted a can of chicken broth for a can of cream of chicken soup, this gave it a slightly thicker liquid and even more flavor. I also took the advice of throwing in chicken boullion (half of a cube) and cut down the salt. Instead of using egg noodles, I made the German Spaetzle Dumpling recipe, also on allrecipes. This was very time consuming because I did make the dumplings (they were delish with this soup!) I used leftover baked chicken breast of which I almost doubled the quantity the recipe called for. I like my homemade soups to be chunky, fillin, and not too watery. I didn't follow this recipe exactly, but it was the best soup I have ever had! The time I think it would take to make the soup would be slightly longer even using the egg noodles. It was worth the time to make the dumplings. I doubled the recipe for my big family of 6, so everything I changed-double those suggestions!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2006-08-02T07:13:17.043
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
1555636
Display Name:

isPro:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a great soup.  I highly recommend using chicken stock instead of broth.  Not just for this, but for anything that calls for broth.  You will find it where the cans of broth are located, but stock will come in a box.  It has a much richer flavor.  Other than that one thing I followed the recipe exactly and loved it.  Thanks for posting.

Display Name:
Debby Sisco

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2894018.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Excellent chicken noodle soup. I used 4 Costco roasted chicken leg quarters -- about 1 lb of meat. (Dark meat is so much more flavorful.) Boiled the bones and skin for stock; strained and added about 24 oz lo sodium chicken bone broth and ~2 tsp Better Than Boullion. Sauted 1 c. each of onion, carrots and cellery in butter and basil pesto Genovese; added 2 cloves minced garlic, oregano, thyme and Bells poultry seasoning to taste. Added stock, veggies and chicken to a pot with ~2.5 c med egg noodles and simmered for ~ 15 minutes.  Hubbie loved it  as is. I added garlic pepper and a drizzle of half and half to mine to make it slightly creamy. Perfect!

text:
Easy to make with a pleasant Italian vibe from the basil and oregano. Prep time was about 15 minutes in order to rinse and chop the veggies. Next time I'll cook the noodles separately so they don't soak up the broth when storing. Will also saute carrots and add some fresh garlic to the saute mix near the end of cooking before adding to pot. This is a great basic recipe. I'll try using traditional seasonings next time to make more like Grandma's! If I have time, I'll also simmer the chicken bones in the broth and then remove them before adding the other ingredients to add even more flavor.

text:
I used 1 32oz carton of Trader Joes organic chicken broth and 1 32oz carton of TJ's vegetable broth and 32 oz more of chicken broth from cubes because I wanted more broth. I used 2# chicken, 5 cloves minced garlic, added celery salt (didn't have celery), 3T dried minced onion, couple pinches of Thyme, 3/4t dried oregano.

I saute the cubed chicken in olive oil, cooked the egg noodles in separate pot, al dente, sauted the carrots in butter till barely tender then added chopped garlic for another minute. Added all together in pot. 

cube the chicken on the small side.

text:
THE BEST super quick chicken noodle soup recipe!!!!! It takes virtually no more than the time it takes to strip a rotisserie chicken to make this soup! If you buy the pre-cut celery/onion/carrot mix it’s even quicker. I only cook for 1 so when I make this I don’t usually add all the noodles at once since I tend to spread the soup out over several meals. I usually boil up a fresh batch of noodles about half way through my consumption and then they don’t get mushy. Perfect comfort soup.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I use this as a guide every year to make my annual leftover Thanksgiving turkey noodle soup. 

Instead of chicken broth, I use the broth left over from my baked in a bag turkey and make up with any needed broth with chicken broth. I do not use the full 1/2 teaspoon of oregano and basil but more of a pinch of each because of the aromatics that I use in the turkey and in turn the broth. I salt and pepper to taste after that. Also use a lot of the dark meat instead of breast and because most do not eat the dark meat, so this makes it into the soup. 

The my now TTNS (Thanksgiving Turkey Noodle Soup) is always a hit and using this recipe as a guide works out fantastically!

text:
Such a easy and delicious Chicken Noodle Soup! I added more chicken meat and noodles to this dish to make it a fuller meal. Also added some garlic powder (would’ve used cloves) and 8 whole black pepper with the spices as well. The only thing that is tedious is the prepping. Give yourself a couple hours to cut the chicken, celery, carrots and onions before cooking. Also use the right cuts for your veggies and chicken (I used bite size cuts because I have hungry little nephews & nieces). But overall this soup is a 10/10 hands down!

text:
This my go to for chicken noodle soup! I’ve made it countless times! Don’t skip the veggie broth because it really improves the flavor. The only thing I do different is cook the chicken separately. I find that whenever I boil chicken, it releases a white residue into the soup so I just prefer cooking it beforehand! Otherwise it’s a really great chicken noodle soup!

text:
Great base recipe for a simple and delicious chicken noodle soup. I used thyme, rosemary and a bay leaf instead of the oregano and basil. Also, all chicken stock instead of veggie and chicken broth. I used all of the meat from a rotisserie chicken, including the dark meat, as opposed to white meat only. I weighed it out and it’s almost exactly one pound of meat, so perfect! Finally, I use about 2 1/2 cups of noodles, because who doesn’t love more noodles, right? Tastes just like homemade.  I’m making it for the second time tonight.

userID:
23904990
Display Name:
rreedneb
isPro:

3
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The entire family loved it! I used 2 Tbsp of butter, sautéed the onion and celery for about five minutes and then added the carrots and sautéed another 5 minutes, added the chicken and spices (and a pinch of rosemary) and just let it sit on the burner with the heat off for 10-15 minutes. I think this let the spices really meld to the chicken and veggies. I then used stock packets that you add to 3 1/2 cups of boiling water (x3) instead of the broths, heated that separately and then added to the rest. Brought that to a simmer and then added homemade egg noodles! (I actually let it simmer for maybe 30 minutes before adding the noodles, I didn't want the noodles to overcook, so I waited until everyone was here). I probably added more like 3 cups of noodles and I have no idea how much chicken, because I didn't weigh it. I actually cooked some chicken breasts and thought I had enough until just before I added the noodles and then decided that I needed more. I happened to have a large can of chicken that I was able to add, and it made it just right. This was my first time making noodles too - you can do it, my husband loved the noodles.
Review:

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed the top reviewers and added garlic with the onions. I didn't have basil but I had fresh thyme which was lovely, didn't have vegetable broth so I only used chicken, and  I made the noodles in their own pot to avoid the starchy, unfreezable glue you get when you cook the noodles in the soup. I ended up adding a cube of chicken bouillon to improve the flavor profile: I think the broth you choose is critical and mine was too salt-free mild to offer a lot of flavor. My husband said this was the best home-made chicken noodle recipe we've tried yet.

userID:
25242356
Display Name:
Najma Smith
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6418973.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this soup Thursday night and by Friday morning it was finished!  I actually made every thing from SCRATCH/fresh. I do not use can chicken and I did not have any broth. What I did was saute my celery and carrots in butter, added  basil and oregano.  Sauteed some more.  Added my onions and 3 cloves of garlic,  chopped/minced. I cut my chicken breast in bite size pieces,  SEASONED IT VERY WELL with garlic powder,  onion powder, chicken seasonings, pepper and Tony's no salt seasoning.  I boiled the chicken for a few minutes.  I then added the chicken to the pot of veggies and let that cook all together.  I then added the broth that I made ( from the  chicken) to the pot of veggies. I let that boil for a few minutes while I cooked my egg noodles half way done.  Once they where half way done,  I drained them and added them to the pot.  I let that cook on low until the noodles where done,  to my liking.  I made some hom6 corn bread and both was delicious.  My family had seconds and kept giving me compliments on the soup and how I should have made more along with the cornbread. It was my first time making a chicken noodle soup and it was a hit! I do not measure my ingredients so I can not tell you how much seasoning I used. I did add vegeta seasoning when all ingredients was in one pot. The broth was very good and tasty. Definitely a must try!

text:
Good little recipe. I followed the recommendation to add a couple of dashes of poultry seasoning, a pinch of thyme and to cut the chicken into bite sizes and cook it while the recipe boils - it worked well however I may swap out chicken breast  for chicken thighs or ground chicken to keep the moisture. This could easily be done with a chicken from Sams or Costco too.  I did use the better than boullion broth and it really makes a different as it brings a TON of flavor with it.

I've made this both the way listed and some changes. While it is yummy as is (4 stars as I rated), it was a total 5 with the changes made.
I skipped the vegetable broth and added an extra can of chicken broth. Used white and dark meat from a rotisserie chicken. And added about 1/2 tsp dried rosemary.
Next time I think I will dice the veggies instead.

userID:
16021960
Display Name:
Hlr62
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
198
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677179.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I reviewed this recipe when I first made it three years ago. I enjoyed it then, but lately I've made a few changes. To quicken things up, I shred a rotisserie chicken and use a container of pre-chopped onions, carrots and celery. I sauteed them in olive oil, then add the shredded chicken and two 14 ounce containers of chicken stock. I cook the noodles separately and add them to each bowl of soup. I also add, thyme, a bay leaf and fresh ground pepper to taste. I don't add additional salt because the stock has enough. To make chicken corn soup, I simply add a package of frozen corn with the soup. The soup freezes very well. I made it for a friend and she said it was the best chicken corn soup she'd ever eaten. I keep a container of soup with or without corn in my freezer for quick meals or friends.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-12-27T17:20:45.587
helpfulCount:
0

I made this for my son (who is home from college with a wicked cold) last night.  I took the advice from others and included garlic with the carrots, onion and celery.  I also omitted the veg stock.
It was REALLY easy (especially since I used a rotisserie chicken) and really delicious!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did what another person said: "in melted butter, sauté 2 minced garlic cloves, 1 cup chopped onion, 1 cup chopped celery, and 1 cup sliced carrots. Meanwhile, chop 1/2 pound uncooked boneless, skinless chicken breast into bite-size pieces. Add chicken, the broth, basil, oregano, salt, garlic pepper, a dash or two of poultry seasoning, and a pinch or two of dried thyme to the pot of veggies. Bring to a boil, reduce heat, cover and simmer 20 minutes. Meanwhile, cook 3 cups egg noodles according to package directions in a separate pot. Add drained noodles to chicken and veggies, simmer an additional 10 minutes. Only if you want some creaminess, go ahead and add a half can of condensed cream of whatever soup (whatever flavor you choose)"

This recipe was SO good! It reminded me of restaurant chicken noodle soup, but i did make some changes. I added worchestershire sauce and used rotiserie chicken. I also cooked in the carrots with the butter with the celery and onions to soften them some more because last time i made it they were more crunchy then i like, but if you like crunchy carrot then it might be ok to just add when you are adding all of the other ingredients!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5708758.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Love this recipe - I've been making it for years and am just now reviewing.  I usually try to throw all veggies in and saute for a few minutes and then slowly add the broth to help get them soft.  I also cook the noodles separately, and only cook as much as I'll need for that particular sitting.  When I cook the noodles in the broth and save them together (for leftovers), the noodles absorb too much of the liquid.  Other than that - PERFECT recipe.

country:
None
text:
I'm rating this five stars because it's an excellent base recipe and it's very easy to adjust for you or your family's preferences. 

Our changes were: doubled the veggies and added carrots and garlic; added thyme to the seasonings (1 teaspoon); added half a can of cream of celery; cooked the noodles separate; and cooked the chicken separate until it was time to add the broth.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I first added garlic, let that cook for a minute - then I added the onions, celery and carrots. I let them all sweat for about 5-7 minutes. I then added the broths, chicken and herbs (i also added fresh thyme) and let that simmer until carrots were soft. Cooking the noodles in the soup for the whole 20 min makes them turn to mush so I actually prefer to cook those separate and add them at the end. Great taste and a recipe I use anytime a cold is making its way around the home.

text:
Very good and very easy. My family doesn’t like cooked celery so I left it out. And since I’m sick, I just grabbed a bag of frozen mixed veggies (carrots, peas, corn, green beans) and threw that in for the carrot portion since it was easier. It was really good. I also added a bit more noodles per request of my husband. 
I added some bouillon for extra flavor (I usually make chicken broth/stock myself, so I added bouillon to make up for not having homemade). My family likes chicken noodle soup just slightly thickened so I also added a small amount of cornstarch. It was perfect!

text:
I made this with a few small adjustments. We shredded the remains of a leftover rotisserie chicken that we had a few nights prior. Didn’t have carrots or celery so we added frozen corn, upped the onion, and added 3 minced cloves of garlic. Also added 1/4 tsp. of rosemary, thyme, and 1 Tbsp. of poultry seasoning and corn starch. Didn’t add the noodles until the last 4 minutes of cooking time since they were on the thin side. We loved it! My husband said it was the best he’s had yet!

text:
Let me start off by saying in no way shape or form am I a cook. I have been known to burn water.  However recently I've decided to give cooking another try even though my husband is a chef. I made this for him tonight because he was not feeling good.  

I nailed it! However it was neither quick nor easy... lol... at least not for me.  I used almost all organic ingredients added fresh garlic because everything tastes better with garlic.  The prep took the longest time for me because I'm still learning knife skills. Also I had to cook the celery much longer than the 5 minutes the recipe called for.  

But in the end it was delicious and my husband gave his approval by cleaning his bowl.  

So .... if I can make this and it come out delicious... then anyone can make this... just expect it to take longer than 30 minutes.  ??

I served it with cheese quesadillas because I didn't have bread for grilled cheese.

text:
This was really tasty (with the garlic added). I always strive to make recipes exactly as written. So, aside from two cloves of garlic, I did so. That said, a reviewer mentioned cooking the noodles separate from just tossing them in... should’ve listened. The 12oz of egg noodles soaked up MOST of the amazing broth which was such a bummer! My next batch I will definitely be making the noodles in a separate pot and then adding to each bowl individually. I also plan to make a double (non-noodle) batch which seems like a ton, but it’s really not! And I will freeze leftovers. Thank you for the perfect noodle soup recipe.

text:
My husband is usually the cook in the house. He was not feeling well and I needed something fast and homemade. I read through the reviews before I began and I'm glad that I did. It was suggested that I add garlic to my onions and celery when I sauteed them as well as my carrots which I did. I also had some fresh thyme and threw that in as well when I began simmering everything. Because we like hearty soups I also followed the suggestion to add more celery and onion then what the recipe called for as well as some finely chopped potatoes. Oh boy is this DEE-LICIOUS and I sure scored some love Bank points with the husband when I served him this. ???????

text:
Tastes delicious and is very simple and quick to make. I found that the egg noodles got super soggy when I added them in when the recipe suggests, so now I add them during the last 5 minutes of simmering and they cook perfectly. I also add about 2 cups of cooked rice right at the end to make it a bit heartier. Also, this makes more like 4 servings if you like a good-sized bowl of soup.

text:
Excellent recipe! Thank you so much! I made it today. I seasoned two chicken breast (thyme,sea salt, black pepper, and season salt) and sautéed them in olive oil . I actually ended up partially sautéeing  the carrots with the celery and onions, until I realized they were supposed to be added after with the other ingredients. So, after separating them from the onions and celery I returned the pot to the stove to let them cook (celery/onions).  I seasoned the veggies with sea salt, pepper, and thyme (didn't have oregano). I then added the rest of the ingredients. I didnt use veggie broth just chicken and a bit of chicken stock. It was soooo good!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
My kiddo stayed home from school with an upset tummy today and requested chicken noodle soup. I made this recipe with herbs of provenance, white pepper, and half of the stock cooking two diced chicken breasts on medium high for a while. Once the chicken was cooked through, I added the rest of the stock and about 16 oz of cream of chicken. I used about a cup and a half each of organic celery and carrots, and cooked them medium high with a lil bit of oil and the half cup of onions with salt and pepper. towards the end I added the butter, maybe a lil more, as well as extra garlic. The family can't get enough of this soup! I promised to make it on the regular from now on. It ended up alittle thick and I want more soup, so I'm going to cook 1 more chicken breast tomorrow with the some more stock and cream of chicken and add it in! The kiddo's feeling better already and it was perfect for a cold winter dinner!

Display Name:

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a DELICIOUS find! I did make a few minor changes. Per other reviewers I cut up the veggies and cooked the carrots along with onion/celery on the stove to make sure that they would all be nice and tender. I transferred the veggies into a large pot, added vegetable/chicken broths and added a pound of diced UNCOOKED chicken breasts (cut into small cubes) added the oregano, basal and pepper and brought to a boil for 20 minutes.  In the meantime, I cooked the noodles per package directions and added the noodles to the large pot after the 20 minutes. I added a pinch of pepper and rosemary to the soup and added half of a can of cream of chicken broth (although next time I may use cream of celery instead). I let this all simmer together for 10 more minutes and it turned out fantastic!! Quick, easy and good. Lots of flavor--Perfect for a cold night/sick day! Can't wait to have leftovers for lunch today!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2018-01-09T18:34:35.707
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
10892713
Display Name:
Saprina Bailey
isPro:
False
followersCount:
7
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
28
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2981238.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Saute 1-2 cloves garlic, 1/4 onion, 2 celery, and 3 carrots in the melted butter for 4 min. Pour in 48 oz of chicken broth, and 14 oz of vegetable broth and 1/2 cup of water. Add fresh oregano and basil, salt and pepper.  Bring to a boil, then add chicken and 2 cups of egg noodles.  Simmer for 20 min.  I used rotisserie chicken (breast and 2 legs).

userID:
8051026
Display Name:
Sdunkley
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/733871.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made Turkey noodle soup after Thanksgiving, from this recipe. 
After boiling down leftovers carcuss (which had remnants of poultry herbs from turkey day), I separately sautéed onion in butter, added minced garlic, sautéed a few more minuted, poured in all broth and meat (a whole dutch oven worth), 6 sliced carrots, thyme,sage,salt, pepper, brought to a boil and reduced to simmer for a couple hours. After carrots were soft, I poured in two cans of condensed cream of chicken soup(this is key). Next I boiled(separately) whole package egg noodles until they were still a little stiff, drained and put them in the soup and simmered all together for little longer until noodles were perfect. Serve right away. 

Its important to note that noodles keep absorbing liquid from the soup so they eventually end up somewhat mushy on the second day but it's still really yummy. 
I do not usually like chicken (turkey)noodle soup but I absolutely loved this recipe the way it turned out.

After reading my review I realized that I really didn't make the recipe the way that the author did. I did use it as a guide to figure out how to make my own though.

text:
Really simple and really good!  I recommend chicken thighs or chicken breast/thigh mix.  I used breast and it was a bit dry...I prefer shredded chicken pieces over breast chunks.  Also added little more onion and celery (basically 1 cup of each instead of 1/2 cup).  Just me and husband in the house and this recipe lasts us a full week.  If you prefer more broth...just keep some stock on hand to add to the bowl as you re-heat for leftovers!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This basic chicken soup recipe is easy to make and tastes delicious. I made some changes to Mary's original recipe because I didn't want as much oregano or basil in my chicken soup, so I only added 1/4 tsps of oregano and basil instead. I also add about 1 tsp of chopped garlic which I saute with the onion and celery. And, I didn't add beef broth to my chicken soup. I just added chicken broth, which didn't change the taste of the soup that much. And I bought strips of pre-cooked chicken which I cut into small cubes for convenience. I also added 2 cups of egg noodles instead of just 1 1/2 cups. I highly recommend this starter chicken soup recipe.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:

userID:
6822186
Display Name:
Raeann Marie
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
33
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674153.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Sauteed an onion, 4 stalks celery, and 1 gigantic carrot in butter ~5 minutes. Moved the veggies aside and added a little butter, put 1-2lbs boneless skinless chicken thighs in the buttered space, cook 5 minutes per side. Added thyme and garlic powder to spices listed above. Used about 6 cups of broth ("Better than Bouillon") and half a package of extra-wide egg noodles. Simmered x 20 minutes. Took chicken out and cut into cubes. Stirred in some fresh parsley, since I had it on hand. Served with buttered crusty ancient grain bread. Delicious, but could use a little more broth or a little less noodles next time.

text:
This turned out to be a good recipe and a good base. I only changed the noodles to spaghetti because I had so much, and I did sauté the carrots with the onion and celery, along with 2 cloves of minced garlic. I also added several shakes of garlic powder at the end. Since I did not have any pre-cooked chicken on hand but wanted to make this, I followed the procedure in the video for the best chicken noodle soup ever on this site. (Placing the raw chicken in my pot and covering it with cold water until completely submerged, and boiling/simmering that with celery  leaves for about 20-25 min. since I only had about a .75lb boneless skinless chicken breast. Next time I will probably add any combo of dried parsley, a bay leaf, dried thyme, peas, and green onion.

country:
None
text:
great recipe. here's what i changed: 

sauted 2 cloves of garlic, onion, and frozen mixed vegetables in the butter (didn't have fresh celery and carrots); used just chicken broth, no vegetable broth; no basil, so added more oregano, and used fennel seeds, cumin seeds, and peppercorn in addition to salt and pepper; i added raw chicken to the broth, not cooked (added the chicken when the broth was cold, brought it to a boil, and then simmered for 15 min), and i cooked the noodles directly in the broth, too (didn't have egg noodles so used linguine instead). also added a dash of soy sauce and vinegar at the end. turned out pretty good!

userID:
3991009
Display Name:
SunnyDaysNora
isPro:
False
followersCount:
421
followingCount:

madeRecipesCount:
1031
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5451024.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I think this would have been a solid 3 star recipe as written, but with a few minor changes it's a 5 star recipe.  I used an entire onion and added a Tbsp of minced garlic when sautéing.  I used two whole chicken breasts cut into bite-size pieces and added them to the sautéed onion, cooking until almost cooked through to allow them to finish cooking in the broth.  At this point I added 10 C of broth (just slightly more than the recipe called for).  In addition to the seasonings which were called for I added about a Tbsp of poultry seasoning, 1/2 tsp of toasted onion powder, 1/2 tsp of roasted garlic powder, 1/2 tsp on parsley, 1/2 tsp of marjoram, 1 tsp of salt, 1/2 tsp ground black pepper, 2 bay leaves, and 2 tsp of sriracha (you can't really identify the flavor in the finished product, but it adds soooo much as far as depth of flavor!!!).  I also doubled the carrots and cooked the noodles separately and then added them at them towards the end so that they wouldn't use up all of the broth when they cooked.  Sounds like a lot of changes, but really the basic recipe stayed the same with some adjustments with seasoning.  My family is loving it right now with some crusty bread on a rainy night!

5

text:
I love this recipe, but I always use uncooked chicken, as it flavours the broth a lot more than uncooked. 

Electric pressure cooker instructions: Make sure your uncooked chicken is cut up into small pieces. Instead of cooking on the stove for 20min, cook on high pressure for 5 minutes, and fast release. The veg, chicken, and noodles will be perfectly cooked.

text:
LOVE THIS. I seriously just made the best chicken noodle I've ever had. I followed a lot of the recommendations. I added garlic when I made the veggies and used raw chicken rather than cooked. I put some rhyme in along with a little bit of chicken seasoning. I also used half veggie and half chicken broth rather than mostly chicken broth. I made the noodles separate and added them after the soup had been cooking for about 20 minutes. I then cooked for another ten minutes once I added the noodles. It's AMAZING. I added some extra carrots and celery and also used the "No Yolks" brand egg noodles, our fave. Came out freaking delicious. HUGE hit. My one and two years olds gobbled it up!

I'm 16 and love to cook, so I'm always using technology to my advantage and looking up reviews for recipes I think would be good and I'm pleased to say this one surpassed my expectations! I've making this soup for about a year now, ever since everyone in my family got sick and miserable and wanted some serious comfort food. Since then, I've altered it bit (not much, just adding more vegetables every now and then) and it seems to be getting better every time I make it! I do recommend cooking the celery, onions, and carrots together and for longer but that's for less crunchy vegetables (something I prefer).
Review:

5

None
text:
My hubby is sick and he doesn't like soup (more of a stew guy) so I had to modify this. I doubled the veggies, minced a large clove of garlic and followed everyone else's advice about sautéing all the veggies. I added extra spices that were recommended in the top review. I only used one carton of chicken broth. I did not precook the chicken. I used 3 cups egg noodles and did not pre-cook them. I added half of a can of cream of chicken soup to thicken it up even more.  It was rich, thick, and chunky...and he loved it. Thanks for the recipe and for all the reviews!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I did make a few changes:
1) I bought store bought rotisserie chicken instead to cut down on cook time even more and I added the bones in the broth as well for a richer taste. I shredded the chicken. 
2) I added cilantro at the end when everything was tender and yummy. Just creates another depth of flavor :) 
3) I added 1 box (48 oz) of chicken broth plus a can (14.5 oz) of it and 1 can (14.5 oz) of veg broth. I also added more water into this because of the eggs noodles reducing the broth. 

Overall chicken noodle soup is relatively simple and you don't have to do too much measuring. I didn't follow the recipes measurements and just made a big pot of this soup and it still came out delicious!

I made home made soup today first time making this! I followed the recipe I added a few changes to the chicken like garlic powder a little old bay seasoning powder , parsley and sauté  until cooked . I made a big pot so I did 48oz of chicken broth and added water! There it is we loved it with grillled American cheese sandwich on the side!!

text:
This is a Great recipe!!  It finally helped me crack the chicken noodle soup flavors I've been looking for.  
I did make a few changes: I sautéed the onions and celery in butter.  For the spices, I used oregano and a dash of thyme (no basil), a bit of garlic powder, and fresh ginger chunks. For the broth, I used only chicken base (no veggie), and shredded/chopped rotisserie chicken.
I will absolutely make this again when I need a quick soup that still has tons of flavor and tastes like it took hours to make!

Made it my own with the following:
Used chicken thighs cut into cubes and seasoned with garlic, Himalayan  salt and pepper.
 Added 2 tbs of turmeric
, and more  carrots, celery
, and  yellow onions
. Used almost 90oz of bone broth.  Added 2 tbs of basil & 2 tbs of oregano. Then added 4 cloves of minced garlic.  

Added more Himalayan salt to taste.  Boiled rapidly then reduced to simmer per recipe.

text:
Easy, fast and delicious.  My suggestion: Cook the noodles separately, toss with very little butter, just so they don't stick together, and keep them in the refrigerator until you are going to use the soup.  Add them just to get them hot.  That way the noodles don't get mushy, and the broth doesn't get cloudy.  Obviously, very easy to reheat everything in the microwave.

text:
Delicious and easy, be careful with how long egg noodles cook.  We really loved this dish as a quick, satisfying meal. We used a rotisserie prepared chicken from the grocery store and some sodium reduced broth. After making a few times, we have found to enjoy it best when the broth has simmered, and we cook the noodle in it, last before serving. This way, the noodles don't get too over cooked and continue to soak up all the delicious broth. With a crusty baguette, this was a great soup dinner that the whole family enjoyed.

text:
I made this and used a cup of celery and one cup of onions instead of the half cup like other reviewers did. My dad, my son, and I were all sick so I wanted some soup and I tried this since most of the soups that I liked they discontinued and this soup is fan freaking tastic. I over peppered it a bit, but no one seemed to mind lol I love pepper anyway.

Also, forgot to add, I sautéed the veggies in olive oil instead of butter. Much healthier and you can't tell the difference.

text:
So easy. So quick. So good. Hubby said he was coming home... 30-40 minutes away. That's when I started prep. It was done cooking when he walked in the door. I used a grocery store rotisserie chicken and just the breast meat. I added the juices from that chicken into the chicken and vegetable broth. Only thing I added was a little chicken bouillon and some water because the vegetable broth seemed to alter the chicken flavor too much. Also, I didn't measure my dry ingredients. I eyeballed the herbs, carrots, celery and onion. I think I used less onions and celery then called for because hubby doesn't like too much onion. This recipe is a keeper.

text:
I was craving homemade chicken soup as I was sick. I made the soup as Brown Sugar Girl suggested. I did not have the cans of chicken broth on hand so I substituted it with a 32 oz container of Low Sodium Chicken broth and chicken broth granules with added water  to taste. I also added 1 teaspoon of Herbes de Provence,  1 teaspoon dried oregano and 1/2 teaspoon basil. I seasoned with Kosher salt and pepper to taste. I cooked bow tie pasta separately and added the soup to the bowl when serving. It came out delicious. Everyone loved it.  Will definitely make again.  Thanks for sharing and the suggestions.

text:
OMG! Let me tell you, I have always been a canned soup kinda gal.  I've never liked homemade chicken noodle soup. UNTIL NOW! I made this today and I have to say it is Fantastic and Flavorful! I followed Brown Sugar Girl's lead and sauteed the onions, garlic, celery and carrots in the butter.  Then put cut up raw chicken in the broth with oregano, basil, poultry seasoning, ground thyme, pepper and a dash of salt.  I used the box chicken broth and box vegetable stock.  I found the broth to be a little too clear for me and needed more umph! So I added two extra large chicken bouillon cubes and it turned out fabulous!! Added wide egg noodles at the end of cooking time! Will definitely be making this again!!

text:
I made this when my youngest was sick with a bad cold a few weeks ago. I only had frozen carrot coins so I used those. I actually saluted the onion in the butter and then used better than base chicken to make the stock. Added the stock to the onions and butter, and incorporated in the carrots, celery, herbs, and a chicken breast. Simmered it all for three hours on the stove, covered. Shredded the chicken breast in the stock and added in the noodles. Cooked for another 10 minutes until the noodles were done. Used all of the ingredients the recipe called for and this soup hit the spot. You will have to add more stock as you see fit to make it more or less soupy and cook the noodles. Delicious! Tons of flavour. Will be making again. Thank you!!

I have made this twice now and just LOVE it! Even my picky kids ate some. I made the recipe as written except I added 2 cloves of minced garlic to the veggies at the saute point. I thought the kids might be more willing to eat it if the carrots weren't in large slices. I used 4 oz of Inn Maid noodles. Delicious on a cold winter day!

text:
The problem was that it lacked the strong chicken flavor you get if you make your own stock with the chicken bones.  To solve that, I added 2 1/2 packet of chicken powdered bouillon to the broth and voila, it drastically improved the flavor and it gave it some depth. The bouillons that I use already has sodium so I didn't need any salt.  I added some bay leaves, fresh thyme, and 1/2 teaspoon of marjoram. I also included fresh macerated garlic; which is nature's antibiotic. This is the perfect prescription for the common cold and very comforting for those cold winter days.

text:
Such a quick, easy, flexible recipe. I had some leftover roasted chicken I wanted to use up. I sliced baby carrots in half lengthwise. Next time, I would leave them whole because I thought they got too soft. I was very loose with the seasonings, did not measure, just through in a few teaspoons of everything. I did not have enough veggie and chicken broth, so I boiled the noodles separately in water so they did not soak up too much broth, then tossed them in while the soup simmered. Amazing how good this tasted for how easy it was, and tasted great as leftovers for several days. It made a good sized pot of soup.

Very good for a quick and easy soup.  Tastes even better after overnight in the fridge and reheated. Where is the time spent chopping the vegetables and chicken?  Total time was more like 45 to 60 minutes start to finish.

text:
This was the best chicken noodle soup I've ever had! Campbell and Progresso soup have weird chicken chunks with tubes on them that disgust me and they're so high in sodium so I've stayed away from them. I've always wanted to make my own soup, I didn't know it would be so easy. As far as changes go, I used 1 cup of celery and 1 cup of carrots, because I love my soup "chunky". The egg noodles I purchased were non yolk and I ended up putting 2 cups of  noodles in. Next time I'll probably put less noodles in I think they absorbed too much of the broth and after 6 bowls of soup there's many noodles left washed up on the beach without broth. Anyways, loved this recipe. I live by myself so I pretty much ate chicken noodle soup for a week haha. Thank you so much!

Extremely forgiving recipe. My gluten tolerance isn't what it used to be so I have made this once with egg noodles, as well as once without the noodles. To sub no noodles I just doubled the chicken and upped the veggies by about 1/4 cup. Each time I made this, I used left over whole rotisserie chickens and just chopped the meat to bite size pieces. I also subbed the one can of veggie broth with a can of water b/c I usually only keep chicken broth stocked in my kitchen.  Delicious!

Display Name:
Julie W.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674164.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe because it's SO forgiving!  Don't like basil?  Leave it out!  Want extra oregano?  Throw some in!  My tips - definitely saute the vegetables in some butter or oil first.  It adds extra flavor to the veggies and reduces the amount of simmering time.  Before adding the broth, I put in a couple spoonfuls of flour and make a roux, stirring really well so all the flour is mixed in and no white remains.  It thickens up the soup a little without having to add any creaminess to it.  I also throw in a couple of bay leaves and a few dashes of poultry seasoning.  I am not a fan of egg noodles, so I usually just small shells instead.   I've also used ditalini, rings, mini bow ties.  Really, any small noodle will work. I've even used rice in place of pasta though.  Just make sure you cook the rice ahead of time otherwise it will literally absorb all the liquid.  As I said, a very forgiving recipe.  Play around with it and add whatever you like!
Review:

5

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Followed advice from some others, and added my own:
(1) In melted butter, sauté 2 minced garlic cloves, 1 cup chopped onion, 1 cup chopped celery, and 1 cup sliced carrots. 
(2) Add whole rotiserie chicken, 48 oz low-sodium chicken brother, 24 oz regular chicken broth, 14 oz veggie broth, basil, oregano, pepper, a dash or two of poultry seasoning, a bay leaf, and a pinch or two of dried thyme to the pot of veggies. 
(3) Bring to a boil, reduce heat, cover and simmer 15 minutes. 
(4) Remove whole chicken and add meat back in. Add wonton noodles cut into strips. Simmer 5-10 minutes.

None
text:
The original recipe was too bland. The changes I made: I cooked the carrots first then threw in the celery and onions. The last minute I added 3 cloves of minced garlic. Then added all the broths, seasoning and uncooked chicken breasts. Once chicken was cooked I took them out  & added 4 cups of egg noodles to the boiling water and began cutting up the chicken into 1/2" cubes. Once the noodles were almost done I added the chicken back in and added a can of cream of mushroom to thicken the soup and let it simmer.

None
text:
This was great! In a Dutch oven, I used 1 tbsp butter, a whole bag of carrots & celery, a whole white onion, celery leaves, fresh basil & fresh oregano from my garden, 2 chix bullion cubes, a shake of chix seasoning rub & lots of salt & pepper. I diced up a pound of chix tenderloins. I actually took the advice of another reviewer, and put all ingredients in the pot, cooked til it boiled. Then reduced heat to a simmer covered for 20 min. Cooked my egg noodles seperate. This has great flavor if you SEASON. Or add some veggies to your stock/broth if you're cooking veggies separate. I will be making this again & again seeing how easy this was. Thanks for submitting:)

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2407310.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I woke up this morning with a cold. When I feel one coming on, all I want to eat is chicken noodle soup. I don't really like all the sodium in canned soups and soup mixes so I decided to make my own. I found this recipe and thought it would be relatively simple to make. After looking at some of the other reviews, I decided to alter it a bit. I added 2 cloves of minced garlic to the onions and celery while sautéing them. I added enough chicken broth to equal 5 cans, thus omitting the veggie broth. Chicken broth adds so much more flavor. I had some poached chicken breast in the freezer but not enough so I added one 12 oz. can chicken breast. I also added a bay leaf and some Herbs de Provence along with the oregano and basil. During the last few minutes it was simmering, I added some frozen green peas as I like them in chicken soup. It turned out wonderful and really hit the spot.

text:
First let me apologize...I did not make this but it is so close to the recipe I use I thought I would mention the differences in case anyone wanted to try. Instead of chicken breast I use a whole chicken raw and cook it in broth or use a cooked rotisserie chicken. Also I do not use vegetable broth...try beef broth. If you don't have egg noodles I use any small pasta or break up spaghetti or linguini. You can also add a pack of chicken noodle soup mix to boost flavour. I hope some of these give you new ideas...Keep Cookin!!!

userID:
15574760
Display Name:
sheiswan
isPro:

followersCount:

10
favoritesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Wonderful recipe I make often when someone is ill or needs some basic comfort.  When I use a rotisserie chicken, I remove most of the meat, then use the flavored skin, wings @bones  which I place in my dutch oven with some broken celery rough chopped onion and some hacked up carrot which I bring to a boil with a carton of chicken stock and some water to cover the bones.  Turn down to a simmer for one hour and strain.  Add the fresh veg, discarding the broth ones and simmer till tender.  I like to keep my noodles cooked and stored separately  so they don't absorb all the broth esp. when stored  or frozen adjust seasonings add 1 tsp sugar...makes a huge difference in rounding out flavor.  If not made for sickies I sometimes give the soup an indian flare with curry powder and cumin.  Other times I do oriental with soy, sesame oil,oyster sauce and add bok choy, baby corn etc. low sodium everything .

We loved it!  I had raw chicken pieces thawed from the freezer so I followed the directions and after the broth was added to the pot, I put the chicken in the pasta strainer insert so the chicken could simmer in the broth. text:
BEST SOUP EVER!  I will never eat chicken noodle soup from a can again!  I doubled the veggies and the seasoning amounts.  I also added garlic, carrots, a 29 oz can of sweet corn, 3.5 cups rotisserie chicken (mostly breast and some thigh), and other seasons (garlic salt, onion pepper, bay leaf, lemon pepper).  It took a LOT of salt to give it flavor for some reason, but it ended up great.  My soup came out as more of a stew consistency, but I like it that way.

text:
Love !!! I make this often & I just tried it W/ rotisserie (thanks to other reviewers!) SO much better & SO much easier!!! Delicious ! Only thing I do different is add more garlic & double the veggies. I use all chicken broth, 1/2 low sodium & 1/2 regular , no salt needed. Just Xtra pepper and I use whole wheat egg noodles  . You would never notice the difference, I add them 10 minutes before serving. I don't find an issue with them loosing their spiral after couple of days - still Delicious !!!!

Added everything together then the last ten minutes added the noodles. I thought could use more vegetables at first but came out fine with what's called for. My three old son was sick and had most ingredients on hand already, him and my husband loved it! A nice cozy quick soup. Will definitely make again!

text:
I used frozen vegetables and canned potatoes, as well as frozen grilled chicken chunks and still, probably the best stew I ever made.  The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is that the soup, by recipe, is a little bland and needs more Oregano and Basil.  I also found that a bit of Garlic, or Garlic powder help.  But overall, a great flavored and super simple chicken soup.

text:
This was a great recipe! I was looking for something basic to start with and modify to my own tastes and this was it. I wasn't feeling well and wanted to make some chicken soup but obviously wasn't feeling like slaving over the stove all day.  It went together quickly and easily and I saved time by using pre-cut carrot chips.  The only thing I did spend time on was deboning the rotisserie chicken I used instead of canned chicken - and I'm glad that I did, it was more flavorful than canned would have been.  Great recipe!

Got a cold funk & just knew a good ole chicken noodle soup recipe would do the trick!  First time making this and it was EASY and very good.  I added salt & other spices as I went along and just tasted to get the proper flavor for me and my fella. country:
None
text:
Great recipe! I do as others suggested...saute a couple minced cloves of garlic and add thyme with seasonings. I saute the Celery, onion and garlic. Add the stocks and already cooked chicken (sometimes I use a roaster chicken that's already cooked from the grocery store) add the carrots and seasonings and bring to a simmer until carrots are a little tender then add the uncooked noodles to finish it up. I feel the noodles soak up more flavor being cooked in the soup rather being cooked in a separate pot.

text:
Very simple to make! I had chicken in the crockpot, so just shredded/chopped that. I used two chicken breasts. I also used one carton of reduced sodium chicken stock and one veggie stock (I believe 32 oz each). I didn't have the right noodles, so I used Orzo pasta. It was good, but I'll definitely try it with egg noodles next time. I also had to add water the second day because the pasta soaked up most of the liquid. I used about 1 cup each of celery and carrot and 1/2 cup onion. It made a ton of soup - probably 10 servings. Very good, quick and perfect to put together for a weeknight dinner.

text:
My first time making chicken noodle soup was a big success!  This is a great basic recipe.  Like most, I adjusted the ingredients a bit. But rather than go through all that, my only suggestion would be that you cook the noodles in the broth like the recipe states.  Many reviewers suggest you cook them beforehand then add before serving. But I think cooking them in the broth added so much flavor to the noodles themselves--they could be a meal on their own!  UPDATE:  My family ate this in 3 days and asked for more.  So I am making another batch tonight with the rest of the roast chicken and will always double this recipe in the future!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I made this soup to take to my mother-in-law in the hospital today and only made a few modifications.  I first substituted olive oil for the butter and sauted carrots and celery, then removed them from the pan and continued with the onions and garlic.  I also revoed these from the pan.  I brought the stock (swanson's no salt chicken broth) to a boil and added seasonings (no salt).  In the meanwhile, I chopped uncooked chicken tenderloins into small bites.  Once boiling, I dropped the chicken into the broth, then added the rice noodles and cooked until tender.  When the noodles were cooked through, I added the cooked vegetables back to the pan and added some chopped cilantro.  The soup was EXCELLENT!

text:
NOTE:I recommend keeping the noodles separate and add them to your portions as you eat it, this will prevent the leftovers from getting starchy and the noodles soaking up all the broth and going to mush.  
My tweaks: added a little more carrots and celery, fresh thyme and rosemary sprigs and I used a combination of bouillon and stock from a carton (not a can.)

text:
Fantastic! You can't go wrong with this one. I had some chicken tenderloins that I had cooked, sprinkling them with oregano while they were cooking. I keep them in the fridge to toss into salads. Since it's a very cold day, I wanted soup and this recipe fit the bill. I used the tenderloins, didn't add the oregano since the tenderloins included it. I added several sliced mushrooms, and some leftover canned Italian green beens? I also used some chopped fresh basil. Honestly, this tasted like it cooked all day to perfection! I think you can add whatever veggies you like and it will turn out just fine. Thanks for sharing, MARYVM! I will be making this one often!

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2013-10-01T05:14:18.067
helpfulCount:
0
userID:
3735949
Display Name:
amy
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
192
favoritesCount:
771
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Changed according to reviews already given be others.  I sauteed 2 cloves of minced garlic, 1 cup carrots, 1 cup celery, and 1 cup of chopped onions in 2 T of margarine.  For the broth, I used a 32 oz container of chicken broth, one 14.5 oz can of chicken broth and two 14.5 oz cans of vegetable broth.  I cut 1 lb of chicken into bite sized pieces and put them in the pot raw when I added the broth (so they chicken is boiled and cooked in the 20 minutes of simmering.)  I added a dash of poultry seasoning.  While the chicken and broth boiled for 20 minutes, in a separte pot I cooked 3 cup of dry egg noodles.  Drained the noodles.  After the 20 minutes, I added the noodles to the broth/chicken pot and continued to simmer for 10 minutes.  Everyone loved it.

text:
I just made this soup.  The vegies, broth and seasoning were spot on.  I did, however use my own chicken broth made from a rotisserie chicken carcass - made a big difference I think.  The single thing that was bad, was the chicken.  Maybe I poached it too long, but, I just think that simmering cooked chicken for another 20 minutes is overkill.  I should have known better.  The noodles were also slightly overcooked.  i don't think they need to simmer for the whole 20 minutes.  Fixing those two things will make this soup really really good.  Next time, it will be perfect!

text:
I've never made Chicken Noodle Soup before.. I've never even made soup and now i can't wait to do it again. So much better than from a can!.. But that doesn't really set the bar very high. Taking from some other reviewers I added a minced clove of garlic, the chopped carrots, and a CUP of chopped onions in the initial sauté. I cut up a raw chicken breast and cooked it separately with salt and pepper and then added in the last 10 minutes of simmering. I also put 2 cups of raw egg noodles and 2 fresh thyme sprigs in the mix. I wanted to make this for my boyfriend who has a cold but i can't help but want to eat all of it myself. Excellent recipe!

This recipe rocks!  I like the texture of chicken that is boiled and then cut up.  So I did boil a whole chicken and then used part of this broth for the remainder of the total needed.  I used 1- 32oz. package Swanson chicken plus 1-14.5 oz vegetable broth. I liked the suggestion to add two cloves of garlic and a pinch of thyme and pinch of poultry seasoning. I am making for the second time today.  This is the perfect recipe to warm you on a cold day - delicious!

I added a little more carrots, chicken and noodles than the recipe called for, but I like soup with more substance and less broth. Great recipe, it's a keeper!

text:
This is a comforting yummy soup. I would prepare as-is to comfort a sick friend, but in my case I used cayenne pepper, garlic, and an additional sprinkle of Italian seasoning to make it more flavorful.  Sometimes I add a handful of fresh spinach at the very end to maximize the nutritional value without significantly changing the flavor. I also cook the noodles separately in broth and add them to the individual bowls to prevent them from becoming soggy.  Yum!

userID:
9121628
Display Name:
Maria Ro
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
8
favoritesCount:
56
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/904823.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Absolutely delicious! A few things I did from reading previous comments:

1. Cooked the onion, celery, and carrots with a tablespoon of minced garlic and butter in the pan. Helped to make the carrots more tender by the end. 
2. Used a small rotisserie chicken from the grocery store and kind of shredded the chicken. 
3. Cooked the egg noodles separately at first - to al dente - so the broth wouldn't get starchy -then added them to the entire pot of soup before boiling. 
4. Once everything was in the pot - boiled and simmered as directed. 
5. Served with shredded PARMESAN CHEESE! This is the last part that really makes the flavor pop! A heavy sprinkle on top of your personal serving --- Mmmmm!

text:
I've made variations of this a few hundred times. I would add a touch of garlic to the flavorings. Variations might include a pasta like tortellini, broccoli florets, fresh green and yellow beans cut to about 3/4 inch and some torn up chard or baby spinach tossed in at the end of cooking. I usually add regular olive oil to the butter for the saute.

text:
LOVE LOVE LOVE this easy recipe!!  My 3 kids are picky eaters & always ask for 2nd's! As I type this Im making it - my daughter who is sick just came downstairs & said "mom, it smells SO could, I cant wait to have some".   
I double the recipe so I can freeze 1/2 for later.  I use roastier (sp?) chicken frm Costco.  Also frozen "Homestyle" Egg Noodles (by the frozen ravioli etc) - they make the soup extra delish!! I put them in frozen as I cook the soup. It is much better the next day - after the spices,etc.. marinate!

text:
Pretty good, not Panera chicken noodle soup soup but a close second.  I used 3 cans chicken broth, 2 veg broth.  Added twice as much celery and carrots and even extra chicken.  Cooked the noodles separate and kept them that way- just added them to each serving as we ate this soup over a few days.  Will make again!  Used a rot chicken for ease of prep.  Lots of veggies so healthy but will likely use lower sodium broth next time- not b/c it was too salty but just to try to make it healthier.

text:
This is a great soup!  Super easy and honestly tastes homemade.  I wouldn't tell anyone it isnt.

I use all the ingredients this soup calls for and then add dried Tarragon.  My mom has always added this to her chicken noodle soup and it adds another dimension to the soup.  Try it and let me know what you think by adding in 3/4 to 1 Tablespoon of dried Tarragon.  I know it defeats the purpose of this recipe BUT if time allows, I also let this soup simmer for 2-3 hours.

text:
Good recipe with a few tweaks. Instead of adding the veggies to the broths, spices, and chicken pot right away, I set them aside and instead added 2 carrots, 2 celery stalks, and ½ lg onion cut into large chunks.  After about 20 minutes, I took out the veggies and added new onion, celery, and carrots as the recipe called for – then simmered for 20 minutes.  I omitted the noodles.  Be careful with adding salt – broth can be very salty already.

text:
This was a very good & quick soup! I took Brown Sugar Girl's advice & sauteed garlic, onions & carrots before adding the rest of the soup to it. I left out the celery cause my husband is not a fan. 
I cooked 2 chicken breasts in oil & put some pepper, garlic powder, old bay seasoning & cayenne on them as well.  I also used two 32oz chicken broth & the 1 veggie broth. My only complaint was the noodles were too soggy for my liking but the soup itself was great! Next time I will simmer the soup for 20 mins as directed but not add the noodles until the last 7 mins so they cook as directed on the package!

I made Sarah’s Dry Rubbed Chicken and had leftovers, so I used them to make this soup.  I doubled the noodles and added a few green peas that needed to be used.  And instead of using the seasonings called for, I added about 1 t. of the dry rub in Sarah’s recipe. It was excellent chicken noodle soup!  Hubs had been asking for chicken noodle soup, and he was very pleased with this, as I was.  I did cook my noodles separately, so I could freeze the extra soup and noodles (separately) for another couple of meals.

text:
Delicious!  Easiest chicken soup I've ever made and it tasted great.  Made a double batch.  I used vegetable stock and chicken bouillon cubes dissolved in water instead of canned broth, will try the canned next time for comparison.   I cooked my chicken breasts separately for exactly the purpose of avoiding the problem the poster below me had.  Cut and added to the soup when they were done.  Also, cooked my noodles separate, divided the soup in half and added noodles to that nights portion - froze the rest in single size servings (w/o noodles).  Great recipe, thanks for sharing it.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really good and really easy. I did double this recipe. I doubled all ingredients except the carrot. I had leftover, cooked frozen chicken breast that I used in this recipe. I used only 1 tbsp of olive oil to saute the onions, celery and carrots before adding the remaining ingredients. I used broken up spaghetti noodles because I didn't have anything else in the house. The spaghetti noodles measured out to be 1 1/2 cups total dry, not cooked before I added them to the soup. I used 2, 32oz boxes of Swanson chicken broth. I added 1/4 tsp of pepper and no extra salt. It was so good for lunch with a homemade loaf of bread. I will be making this again! Thanks!

text:
Nice basic and easy recipe that I will definitely use again.  As other reviewers have done, I used 1 cup of onion and 1 cup of celery instead.  I also sauteed the carrots with the celery and onion at the beginning and then just added the raw chicken and cooked until no longer pink.  The only other things I did differently is used probably closer to 2 1/2 to 3 cups of egg noodles and about 1/4 tsp. of thyme.  I may try adding some condensed soup next time for a more creamy broth.  Not sure what I would do to make it a 5-star recipe, but overall good.

text:
I used to think the only way to make great-tasting chicken soup was to start with a whole chicken and homemade stock, and proceed from there. Wrong!! This soup tastes almost as good as the "totally from scratch" method, but takes about 1/3 of the time to make. And it absolutely blows away any canned soup you'll find on the shelf. Give this one a try. The taste you get for the time you put in can't be beat!

text:
This was truly a quick and easy Chicken Noodle Soup.  I am not a great cook, but this turned out great!  I don't usually like Chicken Noodle Soup, but this one was delicious.  I took one of the recommendations and cooked all the vegetables in butter for a few minutes before adding them to  the broth.  Also added 2 cloves of garlic to the veggie mix and used frozen chicken breasts.  Just boiled them in the broth for about 8 minutes, then shredded and added them back in with all the other ingredients.  This is definitely a new regular on our family menu. Thanks!!

Kind of  Bland, but John loved it when he was sick with cold. I did not have veg. broth, so the next time I will make sure to get some. That might might help make it better. update, 2nd time around, I sauted onion, garlic, celery, chicken breast ect. Guess you can change this around depending on what you have on hand, But I do like cooking noodles with chicken, ( I think it helps thicken broth) But if you are going to freeze this better cook noodles separately. Bet I fix this diff. everytime , great recipe, Thanks!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/279011.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good soup, which will probably be even better tomorrow.  As suggested, I cooked the noodles separately and added them at the end. Also as suggested, I added 2 cloves minced garlic which I sauteed with the onion, carrots and celery in butter and olive oil.  After about 4 minutes, I threw the spices into the veggies and sauteed them all together.  I didn't have vegetable broth, so I used only organic chicken broth, and added  almost a tablesoon of Better Than Bouillon. I used leftover chicken that I had roasted last night, using both dark and white meat. My picky little 2-year-old grandson was running a fever last night, so I made this for his "medicine" tonight, and he lapped it right up.  Yea!  I'm giving this 5 stars for the ease of it along with the very satisfying taste of comfort food.

text:
I have made numerous recipes from this site, and this is the first one that I have been compelled to rate.  I boiled 2 chicken breasts and added sage, garlic powder, chicken buillion & poultry seasoning to the water, and used that as the broth.  I sauteed my veggies and added them to the pot, then shredded the chicken, put it back in, added celery seed and brought to a boil.  I let that simmer for about 30 minutes, then added a cup of water when I put the noodles in.  It was EXACTLY what I wanted.  Thank you for sharing this recipe--this is how chicken soup should always be!!!

userID:
3438287
Display Name:
A PDX Chef

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/178570.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for my sick boyfriend several weeks ago and I had him rate this one although being really sick at the time probably affects the score. Personally I would give it a 4 1/2 but we can both agree that we have had some pretty good homemade chicken noodle soup before. As other users have suggested I used 2 cloves of garlic minced, 1 cup chopped onions, and 1 cup chopped celery. I cooked the chicken in a skillet first in small squares, this made them slightly move vulnerable to moisture and so they absorbed a lot of flavor. However, boiling the chicken and creating a natural broth would most likely been better, if nothing more than to reduce the sodium content found in store bought broths. It was really well seasoned, but my boyfriend had trouble eating it for that reason, and so this isn't recommended for stomach ailments. I definitely enjoyed this with bread, and it was nice being able to make a homemade sick healing food that I will keep around for those pesky colds as well as cold winter days.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/131.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a wonderfully delicious, easy homemade soup! I only made a few simple changes to suit my family's tastes: I added garlic to the onion and carrot to saute, and I also substituted thyme for oregano, but did not use as much because I find thyme stronger. I used regular rotini pasta (not egg noodles) because that is what I had in the cupboard, and that worked just as well. I just used leftover chicken in the fridge from fajitas the night before, and that worked perfectly. The only thing I would do differently next time is to use low-sodium chicken broth and taste it before adding any extra salt, as we found the soup to be slightly salty - but this may have just been the brand of stock I used. Overall, a great recipe that I am sure I will go back to many times!

text:
I made just a few slight changes on this recipe, it had a good taste and was a definite kid pleaser. I sauteed the carrots with the celery and onion. Then, I put the veggies in the broth and let them boil alone while I cooked the chicken. I hate crispy veggies, so I wanted them to cook for longer. I seasoned the chicken with chicken seasoning, garlic powder, salt, and pepper. This made the chicken quite flavorful in the finished product. I also added 2 boullion cubes to the broth. Good for a cold, relaxed day.

I didn't have everything to make this recipe (and I wasn't going to go buy stuff as I'm sick) but it still turned out well. I used 3 cans of chicken broth and two cans of water (about 284ml each). We had an appetite for chicken noodle soup. So I found this recipe and was able to find all of the ingredients around my house. text:
very nice and easy recipe.  I made a couple of modifications based on my busy schedule during the Christmas holidays.  I used uncooked chicken breasts and cooked it in the slow cooker.  The last half hour I put in the noodles.  

My husband who was outside shoveling snow during our huge winter snow storm really appreciated having an awesome soup on hand to warm up with!  

Oh, one other thing I changed... I put in the chicken broth and instead of a vegetable broth, I put in a can of cream of chicken since we like a creamier soup.

I may put just a tad bit a pepper in it as well since both he and I like a more peppery flavor.  However, I felt that it was just perfect :)

city:

None
country:
None
text:
This was great!  I did make several changes, however, because of what I had on hand.  First I poached the chicken in a separate pot as I sauteed one small onion, three cloves of garlic, and the carrot in some olive oil.  I didn't have whole carrots, so I sliced a cup and a half of baby carrots; this cut down on some time since I didn't have to peel them.  I used all chicken broth -- one large container of the low sodium stuff.  After putting it all together, I boiled 2 coups of egg-less egg noodles in a separate pot and then added it to the pot of soup.  For a finishing flourish, I added a handful of chopped parsley to brighten the flavors.  Such an easy and adaptable recipe!  We loved it and can't wait to try it a variety of ways; it would be great with leftover roast turkey breast, I think, or rotisserie chicken meat.  Yum!

text:
I added a TON of veggies (sauteed the raw, but tossed in the frozen and canned later), and increased the seasoning to taste. I kept the chicken at 1/2 lb, boiled it in the broth, chopped it, and added just a tiny bit of noodles. Rotini, broken up didn't soak up the liquid and there was plenty of broth. This recipe is foolproof! Start with the recipe as is, taste it, and season to your liking. For us, 1.5 tbsp italian seasoning, a lot of garlic, and a few dashes of cayenne made it even more wonderful! Any veggies work, even diced tomatoes from the can. This recipe will absolutely be a regular.

I totally changed this recipe, but I wanted to tell people about it...  I used whatever I had on hand in the pantry/fridge... 4 cans chicken broth, 1 can cream chicken soup, a packet of lipton's dry garlic and herb mix, bag of frozen mixed veggies, leftover grilled chicken, my remaining half box of fettucine noodles (broken in thirds)... let it all simmer for about an hour.. very very good! text:
This was great. We had a roasted chicken last night so I pulled off the meat from that, about 3 cups. I added the carrot to the onion and celery, next time I will add some garlic too. Instead of dried herbs, I used fresh. Additionally, I added corn, fresh from the cob and I think that made a big difference, it was a nice crunch, not the same as canned corn. I did not add the noodles, I made them separately so that I can freeze the leftover soup. Added some croutons (when serving) and it was very good and really very easy. Will absolutely make again this winter.My husband just told me that was the BEST chicken soup he has ever had. He was not excited at all about soup for lunch, in fact he wanted me to use the leftover chicken for a pot pie but was in love with the soup after the first bite. The fresh corn really added so much and the crunchy croutons on top were great too.

text:
I pre-boiled a leaftover roaster in a few cups of water and then discarded all skin, cartilege, bones, and chunks of fat.  To that I added one can of reduced-sodium broth, potatoes, carrots, celery (including some of the leaves), a can of corn (my son LOVES corn in EVERYTHING), and the stated salt, pepper, basil, and oregano.  I also added abt 3 tbsp chopped garlic, rosemary, onion flakes, and a bay leaf.  My family LOVED it!  Nothing like an easy, leftover-friendly recipe you can make while cleaning the house and doing laundry in the afternoon!

I was pressed for time and allowed the chicken to cook in the broth, but I think I'll try it a different way next time as the chicken didn't turn out very flavorful.  Great recipe overall.  I definitely will be cooking this again!

text:
This is very similar to my own chicken noodle soup recipe...I use chicken broth with roasted vegetables & Herbs and I throw in a few more spices then this calls for - but overall the same and it always turns out very good.  Just an FYI - if you are going to simmer all day, you do not need to sautee any of the veggies as they will cook enough throughout the day.  I also use frozen egg noodles - just add them the last hour before serving and you are good to go!

This was, hands down, the best chicken soup I've ever tasted! When I saw the ingredients I thought it might be good, worst case scenario, it might be boring. It is beyond good.  My husband, son, and I were all sick and this was perfect: easy, fast, soothing and tasty. I used store-bought rotisserrie chicken and shredding the chicken was the most time consuming step. I added a minced clove of garlic to the sautee (thanks for the tip, previous reviewers!) and used low-sodium broth and extra veggies. It's now on my regular rotation and I keep some frozen for a quick, healthful lunch.

country:
None
text:
I just made this tonight and it was delish!!!  It was just my husband and me so adjusted the recipe like this.... Sauteed about 1/2 cup chopped onion, 1 stalk celery chopped,1 thinly sliced carrot and 1 clove minced garlic.  Then added 3 cans fat-free low sodium chicken broth, 1/4 tsp each of dried basil and oregano...brought to a boil and added a little over a half of bag of Reames egg noodles, cooked for 2o minutes and added about 1 1/2 cups cut up Costco rotisserie chicken left over from night before and heated it through....couldn't be easier and couldn't be better!  Thanks allrecipes.com for such great recipes...LOVE this site!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good! I made some changes:
Putting 1 bay leaf
added more carrots, celery and 1 can of corn.
Didnt have any vegetable broth so i just mix in one can of beef broth.
I cook the onion with butter and olive oil combo, then i added some garlic and mix the vegetables (celery and carrots) in together until softened.
since i dont have any basil i just add 1/2 tsp poultry seasoning. Instead of just salt i put in some seasoning salt and extra garlic powder (we love garlic too much :) 
Instead of just throwing some cooked chicken I put 2 chicken breast with rib bone inside and boiled it together with the vegetables, before i put the pasta in  i just take them out and cut into chunks.
The end result..my bf and his brother cant stop eating :)

text:
This is a good starter recipe like some have already said. I made it pretty much the same except I did use homeade chicken broth. The only thing I did different was saute the carrots with the celery and onion and reduced the amt of oregano to 1/4 tsp because I don't like oregano that much. I also used vegetable bullion/water instead of ready made veggie broth. I couldn't find any in the store! This was my first attempt at making homemade chicken soup and I was very pleased. 
Oh, one more thing, I did add more salt and pepper but I don't consider that much of a change. Everyone seasons w/ salt and pepper differently!

text:
I'd rate this recipe 3 and a half.. First off, the soup was WAY too salty. I didn't even add any salt at all. It may have been the broths, because we bought them salted. Did the ingredients mean unsalted broth? That would have definetly made it less saltier. Plus, instead of 14.5 oz of broth, we used 10 oz and added water. STILL it was salty. I used the amount instructed for the egg noodles, but after the finished look there was barely an adequate amount for four people. So then we added one and a half cups more of the noodles. Even after, when we were eating it, we said that we should've added more noodles. Anyways, the soup would be much better if you added potatoes to it!! I definetly recommend this. We didn't have any on hand, but if we did we would've added it because we add potatoes to all of our soups. Still, the soup was very quick so I give you something for that.

WONDERFUL!! this is a great soup! i doubled this recipe and it couldn't have turned out any better :) the only changes i made were leaving out the onion (just personal preference) and i used 4 cans low sodium chicken broth and 4 regular, just because i was worried it would turn out too salty but i actually ended up adding salt so i don't think it would have hurt to use all regular chicken broth. i also doubled the veggies. although it's august, i still couldn't get enough of this! i sent a bowl to both of my parents and they were very impressed. i also found that this is definitely a cure to my pregnancy nausea which means this will be permanent in my recipe box :)
try this... you won't be dissapointed!!
